status_message:
Falling through the "Cracks"

The Death of Kalief Browder

On Saturday, May 15, 2010, ten days before his seventeenth birthday, Kalief Browder and a friend were returning home from a party in the Belmont section of the Bronx.

As they passed East 186th Street, Browder saw a police car driving toward them. More squad cars arrived, and soon Browder and his friend found themselves squinting in the glare of a police spotlight. An officer said that a man had just reported that they had robbed him. "I didn't rob anybody," Browder replied. "You can check my pockets."

The officers searched him and his friend but found nothing. As Browder recalls, one of the officers walked back to his car, where the alleged victim was, and returned with a new story: the man said that they had robbed him not that night but two weeks earlier. The police handcuffed the teens and pressed them into the back of a squad car. 

At the Forty-eighth Precinct, the pair were fingerprinted and locked in a holding cell. A few hours later, when an officer opened the door, Browder jumped up: "I can leave now?" Instead, the teens were taken to Central Booking at the Bronx County Criminal Court.

Late on Saturday, seventeen hours after the police picked Browder up, an officer and a prosecutor interrogated him, and he again maintained his innocence. The next day, he was led into a courtroom, where he learned that he had been charged with robbery, grand larceny, and assault. 

The judge ordered him to be held and set bail at three thousand dollars. The amount was out of reach for his family, and soon Browder found himself aboard a Department of Correction bus. He fought back panic, he told me later. Staring through the grating on the bus window, he watched the Bronx disappear. Soon, there was water on either side as the bus made its way across a long, narrow bridge to Rikers Island.

Male adolescents are confined in the Robert N. Davoren Center—known as R.N.D.C. When Browder arrived, the jail held some six hundred boys, aged sixteen to eighteen. Conditions there are notoriously grim. In August of this year, a report by the U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York described R.N.D.C. as a place with a "deep-seated culture of violence," where attacks by officers and among inmates are rampant. The report featured a list of inmate injuries: "broken jaws, broken orbital bones, broken noses, long bone fractures, and lacerations requiring stitches."

Browder's family could not afford to hire an attorney, so the judge appointed a lawyer named Brendan O'Meara to represent him. Browder told O'Meara that he was innocent and assumed that his case would conclude quickly. Even the assistant district attorney handling the prosecution later acknowledged in court papers that it was a "relatively straightforward case.

Browder said that, one night soon after he arrived, a group of guards lined him and several other inmates up against a wall, trying to figure out who had been responsible for an earlier fight. "They're talking to us about why did we jump these guys," he said. "And as they're talking they're punching us one by one." Browder said that he had nothing to do with the fight, but still the officers beat him.

On the morning of July 28, 2010, Browder was awakened at around half past four. He was handcuffed to another inmate and herded onto a bus with a group of other prisoners. A grand jury had voted to indict Browder. The criminal complaint alleged that he and his friend had robbed a Mexican immigrant named Roberto Bautista—pursuing him, pushing him against a fence, and taking his backpack. Bautista told the police that his backpack contained a credit card, a debit card, a digital camera, an iPod Touch, and seven hundred dollars. Browder was also accused of punching Bautista in the face.

He never met nor heard of this man.

Browder repeatedly told O'Meara, his court-appointed lawyer, that he would never plead guilty and that he wanted to go to trial. O'Meara assumed that his courtroom defense would be "Listen, they got the wrong kid." After all, the accusation had been made a week or two after the alleged robbery, and the victim had later changed his mind about when it occurred. (The original police report said "on or about May 2," but Bautista later told a detective that it happened on May 8th.)

Not long after arriving on Rikers, Browder made his first trip to solitary confinement. It lasted about two weeks, he recalls, and followed a scuffle with another inmate. "He was throwing shoes at people—I told him to stop," Browder said. "I actually took his sneaker and I threw it, and he got mad. He swung on me, and we started fighting." Browder was placed in shackles and transferred by bus to the Central Punitive Segregation Unit, which everyone on Rikers calls the Bing. Housed in one of the island's newer jails, the Bing has four hundred cells, each about twelve feet by seven.

For Browder, this was the first of several trips to the Bing. As he soon discovered, a prisoner there doesn't leave his cell except to go to rec, the shower, the visit room, the medical clinic, or court; whenever he does leave, he is handcuffed and strip-searched. To pass the time, Browder read magazines—XXL, Sports Illustrated, Hip Hop Weekly—and street novels handed on by other inmates.

Summer is the worst time of year to be stuck in the Bing, since the cells lack air-conditioning. In the hope of feeling a breeze, Browder would sleep with the window open, only to be awakened at 5 A.M., when the cell filled with the roar of planes taking off from LaGuardia, one of whose runways is less than three hundred feet from Rikers. He would spend all day smelling his own sweat and counting the hours until his next shower.

For several years he was a resident of solitary confinement ..... for a crime he did not commit.  He was routinely beaten by guards.

On March 13, 2013, Browder appeared before a new judge, Patricia M. DiMango, who had been transferred from Brooklyn as part of a larger effort to tackle the Bronx's backlog. She was known for her no-nonsense style when dealing with defendants; at the Brooklyn courthouse, she was referred to as Judge Judy. 

His battle to prove his innocence had ended. No trial, no jury, no verdict. An assistant district attorney filed a memo with the court explaining that Bautista, the man who had accused Browder, had gone back to Mexico.   

The ordeal took three years and his childhood.  It was finally over.......And he was changed......he preferred to spend time by himself, alone in his bedroom, with the door closed. Sometimes he found himself pacing, as he had done in solitary. When he saw old friends, he was reminded of their accomplishments and what he had not achieved: no high-school diploma, no job, no money, no apartment of his own.

One day last November, six months after his release, Browder retreated to his bedroom with a steak knife, intending to slit his wrists. A friend happened to stop by, saw the knife, and grabbed it. When he left the house to find Browder's mother, Browder tried to hang himself from a bannister. An ambulance rushed him to St. Barnabas Hospital, where he was admitted to the psychiatric ward. In his medical record, a social worker describes the suicide attempt as "serious."

He learned that he had passed the G.E.D. on the first try. He felt some of his pride coming back.  He found a part-time job, working for a friend who runs a jewelry business in the same building as Prestia's office, near Wall Street. On May 29th—four days after his twenty-first birthday, and a year to the day after DiMango told him that he would be set free—Browder stood on a sidewalk in front of a Chase bank, handing out flyers advertising the jewelry business. He liked Wall Street—being surrounded by people with briefcases and suits, everyone walking with a sense of purpose. "When I see professional people, I see myself," he said. "I say, 'I want to be like them.' "

He spent more than one thousand days on Rikers waiting for a trial that never happened. During that time, he endured about two years in solitary confinement, been abused by officers and inmates on Rikers.  Surveillance footage shows some of the abuse by guards at rikers:

http://www.newyorker.com/news/news-desk/exclusive-video-violence-inside-rikers

Browder hung himself at 12:15 pm last Saturday. He had just turned 22.  He suffered needlessly and may his soul find peace.  I pray for his family.

status_message:
Good Wednesday Morning!

Two Things that are True.

"That's well known. It's an unfortunate fact that in the male black population, a very significant percentage of them, more so than whites or other minority candidates, because of convictions, prison records, are never going to be hired by a police department. That's a reality. That's not a byproduct of stop-and-frisk," Bratton said.

He added that within black communities, some "15 to 20% of black males have some type of criminal history and that's an issue of great concern in the black community."

This was the result of an interview with NYPD Commissioner Bill Bratton.

Of course everyone went ballistic and started using the usual word "racist"!

It has become so Politically Correct in America today to lie to ourselves; to lie to others and to pretend that we are not seeing what is plainly clear to our "lying" eyes.  Here are  twoof the most popular lies today:

>We tell ourselves that a man can change into a woman and a woman into a man.... biologically just because they want to and they get the right operation.....  we then brand these people as "brave" when in fact  the XY sex-determination system is the sex-determination system found in humans, most other mammals, some insects.  In this system, the sex of an individual is determined by a pair of sex chromosomes (gonosomes). Females have two of the same kind of sex chromosome (XX), and are called the homogametic sex. Males have two distinct sex chromosomes (XY), and are called the heterogametic sex.

So, we can call a man by the name of Herman.... Hermanita, we can do his hair, makeup and buy feminine clothing, remove his penis and insert breast implants and put Hermanita on the cover of Vogue.  The reality is that the chromosomes are still XY which biologically makes Hermanita a male.  The same goes for when Susan becomes Sam except that the chromosomes are XY.  

Given the complexity of the operation(s) and the changes that one's family will go through, people might consider that acts of "bravery" but there are also other descriptive words that might be used.  In this world people are capable of calling themselves anything they want and doing whatever they want but there will be many people who subject themselves to this and become even more depressed with the outcome...  especially those without the reality show and cover-girl potential.

>Another lie we tell ourselves is one based in self imposed guilt and the inability to digest truth in regards to race.  While there ARE many Black men who have never been to jail, it is NOT insensitive to state an honest truth.  Approximately 12%-13% of the American population is African-American, but they make up 40% of the almost 2.1 million male inmates in jail or prison (U.S. Department of Justice, 2009).

Is it because of "racism"?  Sometimes it might be......  that is a reality.  But what is also a reality is that 78 percent of Black children grow up WITHOUT two parents in the home and in many cases without opportunities and supervision.  Some "boneheaded" ideas promulgated by school-systems across the country involve letting them further run wild in school as a means of being "sensitive" to slavery and Jim Crow.  I don't know of any school aged children who have been slaves or through "Jim Crow" laws.  What this allows are children who grow up without the skills and discipline which make it possible to be a success in society.  Bottom line, when they act out in society with the same tactics that the 'sensitive" administrators allowed in school, they might wind up in jail.  

So, when you have such a small sliver of the population committing crimes or getting "locked up", it mathematically leaves a smaller proportion, after other career fields are considered, left to join the police force.  It is NOT the "fault" of "stop and frisk" that these people have received "police records".......  If the "stop and frisk" resulted in "nothing"...... there would likely be no arrest.

In an August 2013, Sentencing Project report on Racial Disparities in the United States Criminal Justice System, submitted to the United Nations, "one of every three black American males born today can expect to go to prison in his lifetime".  And it gets worse......

Several studies have concluded that overall, more black males are in prison than are enrolled in colleges and universities. In 2000 there were 791,600 black men in prison and 603,032 enrolled in college versus 1980, when there were 143,000 black men in prison and 463,700 enrolled in college.  So it appears to be getting worse over time.....  

A new release as September 2012 from Schott Foundation finds only 52% of Black males graduate from high school.  In our "knowledge based society", this often excludes them from finding meaningful and gainful employment which might essentially lead many to crime.  The three top crimes?  (1) Drug offenses; (2) Person Offenses; (3) Property Offenses.  According to one writer, "there are more African American men incarcerated in the U.S. than the total prison populations in India, Argentina, Canada, Lebanon, Japan, Germany, Finland, Israel and England combined."  And this is out of a population of approximately 19 million Black men in the United States.  

Is the answer to "decriminalize" certain offenses such as drugs?  Um... no..... the point is that this is a manner in which money is made.  Wouldn't the other crimes go up as a result?  

The reality of this "truth" is that unless we identify and address the problem, it only get's worse.... it does not go away.  In the face of such rabid deniers and the PC police, NYPD Commissioner Bill Bratton, is the one deserving the description of "Brave".

status_message:
Happy Birthday Hattie McDaniel!!!!

The Original Trailblazer......

Hattie McDaniel (June 10, 1895 – October 26, 1952) was an American actress, singer-songwriter, and comedienne. She is best known for her role as Mammy in Gone with the Wind (1939) for which she won the Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress, making her the first African American to win an Academy Award.

In addition to acting in many films, McDaniel was a professional singer-songwriter, comedian, stage actress, radio performer, and television star; she was the first black woman to sing on the radio in the U.S.During her career, McDaniel appeared in over 300 films, although she received screen credits for only 80 or so.

McDaniel has two stars on the Hollywood Walk of Fame in Hollywood: one at 6933 Hollywood Boulevard for her contributions to radio and one at 1719 Vine Street for acting in motion pictures. In 1975, she was inducted into the Black Filmmakers Hall of Fame and in 2006 became the first black Oscar winner honored with a US postage stamp.

Hattie McDaniel was born June 10, 1895, in Wichita, Kansas, to former slaves. She was the youngest of 13 children. Her father, Henry McDaniel, fought in the Civil War with the 122nd USCT and her mother, Susan Holbert, was a singer of religious music.

In 1900, the family moved to Colorado, living first in Fort Collins and then in Denver, where Hattie graduated from Denver East High School. Her brother, Sam McDaniel (1886–1962), played the butler in the 1948 Three Stooges' short film Heavenly Daze. Another acting sibling of Hattie and Sam was actor Etta McDaniel.

In addition to performing, Hattie was also a songwriter, a skill she honed while working with her brother's minstrel show. After the death of her brother Otis in 1916, the troupe began to lose money, and it wasn't until 1920 that Hattie got her next big break. During 1920–25, she appeared with Professor George Morrison's Melody Hounds, a touring black ensemble, and in the mid-1920s she embarked on a radio career, singing with the Melody Hounds on station KOA in Denver. In 1926–1929 she also recorded many of her songs on Okeh Recordsand Paramount Records[8] in Chicago. In all, McDaniel recorded seven sessions; one in the summer of 1926 on the rare Kansas City label Meritt; four sessions in Chicago for Okeh (late 1926-late 1927) – of the ten sides, only four were issued, and two sessions in Chicago for Paramount (both in March 1929).

When the stock market crashed in 1929, the only work McDaniel could find was as a wash-room attendant and waitress at Club Madrid in Milwaukee. Despite the owner's reluctance to let her perform, McDaniel was eventually allowed to take the stage and she soon became a regular.

After Show Boat she had major roles in MGM's Saratoga (1937), starring Jean Harlow and Clark Gable, The Shopworn Angel (1938) with Margaret Sullavan, and The Mad Miss Manton (1938), starring Barbara Stanwyck and Henry Fonda. She had a very minor role in the Carole Lombard/Frederic March vehicle, Nothing Sacred (1937), in which she appeared as the wife of a shoeshine man (Troy Brown), masquerading as a sultan.

McDaniel was a friend of many of Hollywood's most popular stars, including Joan Crawford, Tallulah Bankhead, Bette Davis, Shirley Temple, Henry Fonda, Ronald Reagan, Olivia de Havilland, and Clark Gable. She would star with de Havilland and Gable in Gone with the Wind (1939).

She was constantly criticized  by members of the black community for the roles she chose to accept and for her decision to pursue roles aggressively rather than rock the Hollywood boat.. Groups such as the NAACP despised her for accepting the roles offered because she played often the maid.  They referred to her as an "Uncle Tom".  She was not associated with civil rights protests and she did not join the Negro Actors Guild of America until 1947, very late in her career.   McDaniel hired one of the few white agents who would represent black actors in those days, William Meiklejohn, to advance her career. realizing that she had to "play the game first, so that she could make a difference later. "  Right or wrong, it was her decision and she was a very successful and shrewd businesswoman.  Even though she was given accolades for her speech when accepting the academy award, she had to sit with her family at a sectioned off table apart from the other actors.  

Hedda Hopper once said that most of McDaniel's career woes came not from the whites but the Blacks undermining and criticizing her at every turn for not being more of a force for civil rights.  She gained a reputation for generosity, lending money to friends and strangers alike regardless of their race.....

She won the right to purchase a white two-story, seventeen-room house in 1942. The house included a large living room, dining room, drawing room, den, butler's pantry, kitchen, service porch, library, four bedrooms and a basement. McDaniel had a yearly Hollywood party. Everyone knew that the king of Hollywood, Clark Gable, could always be found at McDaniel's parties.

The home was in the development of West Adams Heights which had , back in 1902, had a covenant  which restricted "Non-Caucasians" from owning property. For seven years they had tried to enforce it, but failed. Then they went to court....

Superior Judge Thurmond Clarke decided to visit the disputed ground—popularly known as "Sugar Hill." ... Next morning, ... Judge Clarke threw the case out of court. His reason: "It is time that members of the Negro race are accorded, without reservations or evasions, the full rights guaranteed them under the 14th Amendment to the Federal Constitution.

Never the "rabble-grouser"  she simply told the reporters:  "Words cannot express my appreciation."

She died of breast cancer in 1952 at the age of 57.  Thousands of mourners turned out to celebrate her life and achievements. In her will, McDaniel wrote: "I desire a white casket and a white shroud; white gardenias in my hair and in my hands, together with a white gardenia blanket and a pillow of red roses. I also wish to be buried in the Hollywood Cemetery."  

The Hollywood Cemetery on Santa Monica Boulevard in Hollywood is the resting place of movie stars such as Douglas Fairbanks, Rudolph Valentino, and others. Hollywood Cemetery refused to allow her to be buried there, because it, too, practiced racial segregation and would not accept for burial the bodies of black people. Her second choice was Angelus-Rosedale Cemetery, where she lies today

McDaniel's last will and testament of December 1951 awarded her Oscar to Howard University, where she had been honored by the students with a luncheon after she had won her Oscar.The whereabouts of the McDaniel Oscar are currently unknown. It has been reported that the Oscar had been cast into the Potomac River by angry Black civil rights protesters in the 1960s.  

Just a few of her quotes:

"Always remember this: There are only eighteen inches between a pat on the back and a kick in the rump."

"Why should I complain about making $700 a week playing a maid? If I didn't, I'd be making $7 a week being one."

"I sincerely hope that I shall always be a credit to my race, and to the motion picture industry."

"I did my best, and God did the rest."

status_message:
Today in:  1947 - "Lassie Show" debuted on ABC radio. It was a 15-minute show.

The New Lassie (television)

Lassie is an American television series that follows the adventures of a female Rough Collie dog named Lassie and her companions, both human and animal. The show was the creation of producer Robert Maxwell and animal trainer Rudd Weatherwax and was televised from September 12, 1954, to March 25, 1973. The fourth longest-running U.S. primetime television series after The Simpsons, Gunsmoke, and Law & Order, the show chalked up 17 seasons on CBS before entering first-run syndication for its final two seasons. Initially filmed in black and white, the show transitioned to color in 1965.

The show's first 10 seasons follow Lassie's adventures in a small farming community. Fictional eleven-year-old Jeff Miller, his mother, and his grandfather are Lassie's first human companions until seven-year-old Timmy Martin and his adoptive parents take over in the fourth season. When Lassie's exploits on the farm end in the eleventh season, she finds new adventures in the wilderness alongside United States Forest Service Rangers. After traveling on her own for a year, Lassie finally settles at a children's home for her final two syndicated seasons.

Lassie received critical favor at its debut and won two Emmy Awards in its first years. Stars Jan Clayton and June Lockhart were nominated for Emmys. Merchandise produced during the show's run included books, a Halloween costume, clothing, toys, and other items. Campbell's Soup, the show's lifelong sponsor, offered two premiums (a ring and a wallet), and distributed thousands to fans. A multi-part episode was edited into the feature film Lassie's Great Adventure and released in August 1963. Selected episodes have been released to DVD.  Wikipedia

status_message:
Good Monday Afternoon!

Affirmative Action….. is it ever fair?

The United States is supposed to be a "melting pot".  A country made up of many different people, with  variations in lifestyles, faiths, religions, races and backgrounds all "melting" together into what can be considered a harmonious whole, one "pot" of people living together under a common culture, a common set of patriotic values.  Those proponents of multiculturalism, emphasize a fusion of cultures  which maintain and celebrate elements of their own unique culture.  

Why is the idea of a "melting pot" important?  Because it stresses the ideals that we as a nation have "in common" with each other rather than the differences.  Much of the assimilation between cultures occur through befriending, community and intermarriage between the various members of society.  African-Americans are fully culturally integrated into American culture and institutions, however,  more than a century after the abolition of slavery, intermarriage between African-Americans and other ethnicities is much less common than between different white ethnicities, or between white and Asian ethnicities. Intermarriage between whites and non-whites, and especially African-Americans, has long been a taboo in the United States, and was illegal in many states  until 1967.  For this reason, and many other economic ones as well, African Americans have not been able to fully participate in the "melting pot" of America.

Affirmative Action is the policy of favoring members of a disadvantaged group who suffer from discrimination within a culture, many call it "positive discrimination", however, that seems a bit of an oxymoron.    Rather it is a way of favoring members of a disadvantaged group who suffer from discrimination within a culture.  This is seen as the remedy for those who have been left out of the "melting pot".  Affirmative action in the United States tends to focus on issues such as education and employment, specifically granting special consideration to racial minorities and women who have been historically disadvantaged in terms of education and employment.    

There are now a couple of "new twists" that I would like to discuss…..  If you go to HarvardNotFair.org, you'll find yourself on a page that says this: Were You Denied Admission to Harvard? It may be because you're the wrong race.  OK……. A lot of people DON"T get into Harvard.  The competition is stiff, and there are many facets to getting accepted….  This site is curtesy of "The Project for Fair Representation" .   Edward Blum previously backed Fisher v. Texas, an affirmative action case that was brought before the Supreme Court in 2012. In that case, Abigail Fisher, a white woman, claimed she was denied admission to the school, while lesser-qualified blacks and Latinos got in because of affirmative action. (The Supreme Court sent the case back to a lower court for further review, and it's still going through the appeals process.)
This case and a few others involving the top level schools are making the argument that affirmative action policies don't just hurt whites; they also hurt Asian-Americans, maybe even more so.  Schools should try to achieve racial diversity –  but not in a manner that would disadvantage other students by holding them to a different standard based upon the color of skin.

The lawsuit filed against Harvard cites an Asian-American student who was denied admission despite being valedictorian of a competitive high school, achieving a perfect ACT score and a perfect score of 800 on two of the SAT II subject exams, and participating in numerous extracurricular and volunteer activities. The applicant, the lawsuit states, was "denied the opportunity to compete for admission to Harvard on equal footing with other applicants" due to his race.

Many Asian students are offended and feel that they are "disadvantaged"  by the stereotype that paints them all as over-achieving and affluent.  The truth is, however, that as a "minority group" .  As a whole,  they can boast the highest high school graduation rate of any race in the country.  Princeton researcher Thomas Espenshade and Alexandria Walton Radford of RTI International found that Asian-identified students had to score 140 points higher on their SATs to gain admission to prestigious colleges compared to white students.

So, if we are to restore our republic to "the shining city on the hill", is it wise to punish success?  Because that is what we are doing when we socially engineer the winners and the losers based upon something as benign as the "skin color".  The myth that most Asians are affluent with exceedingly high IQ's is simply that … a myth.  I have been a host to two Chinese exchange students over the past four years.  They work hard, even though by Chinese standards both students were from affluent homes, the goal was to make the "family proud" and not bring shame by returning to their country "unaccomplished".  My first Chinese daughter, Lynn, scored 700 on the math portion of the SAT, her parents were beside themselves with anger and over the next few weeks she received tutoring over the internet  and pamphlets to help her get a "better score".  The next score was "perfect".  My manicurist is from Viet Nam.  He and his wife do manicures and pedicures seven days a week in their shop to keep their two sons in the most expensive private school in South Florida – the total cost $47,000 per year.  All he talks about are the grades and he will pull out their grade report to show everybody.  On the weekends, they come to the shop to clean up.  And then they (the sons) "hang out with friends" and play games like golf, the  parents always seem apprehensive about that and the father told me he does not like it but they have to "do that in America" to become American.  
  
Perhaps, they are the winners in the equation, after all.  At the end of the day the stereotypes and assumptions provide them with the esteem that they need to keep meeting and exceeding expectations.    The door swings both ways……

status_message:
Don't Do it; Don't Do It; Have a heart.

When my youngest daughter was 11 I thought that she would look cute with a "pixie" cut.  She went along with it and she looked like a very young Halle Berry or Season Hubley.  She has really cute small features and it was so very fashionable.  One problem, she is really small and while I thought it was fashionable she endured a lot of teasing at school.  They would pretend to line up the boys on one side and the girls on the other and pretend that did not remember she was a girl for example..... I was wrong and I was selfish.  Her hair is now 3 feet  long and she is allergic to hair cutting and I oblige.  I say this to mean that shaming a child is wrong but shaming by cutting their hair is awful.  I hope this father can forgive himself.

status_message:
Good Friday Morning!

The Return of Rick Perry!

It was hot, very hot in the hangar but one thing is certain..... Rick Perry supporters do make a compelling point:with the following statement::  

"Imagine a president who's worn the uniform and knows what it's like to serve," retired Navy SEAL Pete Scobell told a crowd of Rick Perry supporters Thursday as they waited for the former Texas governor to announce his second run for the presidency in a stifling hot airplane hangar."

Imagine that.  Imagine how different the state of the Middle East would be without the chaos that ensued after the completely chaotic foreign policy gaffes of the current president and his administration.  Imagine a better response in Benghazi, the misreading of the so-called "Arab Spring" which subsequently heralded in the rise of ISIS or ISIL....... Imagine that Iraq would not be lost and Syria would not be on the verge of being lost.  Imagine that several respected generals and advisers would still have been available to give their very valuable advice.  Imagine that 5 Taliban "superstars" would not have been swapped for a low life deserter by the name of Beau Bergdahl and imagine that his mother in her sprightly spring frock and dad in his big Tali-beard would not have been on hand to deliver a message in a middle eastern dialect.

Imagine..... a domestic policy that would not have included race riots with fictitious stories such as "hands up don't shoot".  Imagine the  United States without the urban strife that would produce a young Mike Nifong in the form of a Prosecutor by the name of Mosby who at this very moment is scrambling to put together a case that won't blow up in her face by suppressing evidence from an autopsy.  Imagine her not standing on television delivering an INSANE speech about her being a crusader for the rioters who's "time has come" and then has her mother text something about her name being headed for "stars" while she jumps on stage with Prince.  Imagine Baltimore without the animus towards police that has turned it into a place where for the month of May there were 42 homicides and violent crime is on the "upswing" ----- it was already up.... how much higher can it go?

Imagine a country without Al Sharpton as a presidential level adviser. or where a curious woman who is also a State Department spokesperson - Marie Harf',  asserts that all the terrorists need to stop attacking are jobs and the ability to get small business loans to start small shops and those who don't understand this are not as smart as she is..

Imagine no Obamacare with all of its upcoming "surprises".  These surprises don't include anything more than more money out of your pocket; 

Just imagine.....  the daydream rather than the nightmare to come unless we get this next election right.  

We have a great field of candidates, very capable of correcting the very tough situation in America.

Imagine.....A country of "Americans"...... not hyphenated Americans divided by gender, race, color, religion, income, class, etc....... at least in terms of direction.

Why don't we imagine?

status_message:
Last Response about the Duggars

After spending most of the morning responding to constant assaults regarding the Duggar family, I realize that many people no longer question, they advocate.  As long as I am writing about the ills of the left, Black people, Hispanics, the ghetto or illegal immigrants, it is golden.  But the minute the shortcomings of what many consider sacred, then the "disappointment" begins and the attacks start.

Sorry, that some of you feel that way, but when I see something that does not ring true...... I am going to speak out.  It is a sad state of affairs that some of you can not fathom how terrible it is that an adolescent boy "fondle" or fiddle with his sister or any other young girl.  Not once, not twice but three times.  It was like he was compelled.  We must get smarter than that.  

 Jim Bob Duggar finally reported Josh's conduct to State Trooper Joseph Hutchens. Hutchens, who is currently serving a 56-year prison sentence for child pornography, claims that Jim Bob lied to him. According to Hutchens, Jim Bob said that there was only a single instance of Josh molesting one of his sisters.

Hutchens never filed a formal report. By the time police got wind of the incidents again, the statute of limitations had expired.

I understand that many of you are defending them from a "place of hurt" because many have either endured abuse or know someone who has.  I advocate for them.  No-one is considering the girls.  

As for "counseling", that story has changed also:

Jim Bob reportedly told church elders — and presumably the police — that Josh was sent in 2003 to a Christian program with "hard physical work and counseling." Michelle later told the police that "Josh did not receive counseling and instead had been sent during that time to a family friend who was in the home remodeling business." 

Sorry.....  re-doing a kitchen is not the same as curbing compulsions.  The posted story was not about the Duggars per se but about the millions of girls suffering in silence and bringing that hurt to adulthood.  I think much of the discussion came from a place of hurt.  No one even noticed the theme of discernment.

status_message:
Good Thursday Morning!

The Duggars , the Interview and the Girls.....

(Please read before commenting)

There is always vitriol and curious anger surrounding any discussion of the Duggar family.  This comes both from the left and the right since I deal with both on a daily basis.  I have never had any feelings one way or the other because I am part of a very large family and I really felt that it was none of anyone's business how many children a family decides to produce as long as they are able to take responsible care of each of the members.  Personally, Allen and I felt that our top level was two and that was all we had ---- two children and that too was our own business and what was right for us.  

But this story was different.

No doubt so many people have formulated their defense prior to hearing anything about this family as well as there are those who are "bloodthirsty" in their "aha" moment. but once again this story is different.  Personally, I have always been suspicious of any family or movement that removes the individual from utilizing the very gift from God, and that is discernment.  Discernment: is the heightened ability to read or hear a teaching, to encounter a problem, or to consider a proposed course of action, and then determine whether the source behind the teaching, problem, or action is divine, merely human, or satanic.

The Duggars, by their very prolific gift for producing children, have been able to singularly produce their own school house of children.  They home-school (which can be a good thing), they associate with like minded people and they attempt to marry off their young to people with like minded characteristics.  Their days are spent centered around the family and the often grueling aspects, at least for the girls, of filling every waking hour with tending for younger siblings.  Believe me, that is not easy for a child.  My mother often thanks me for babysitting my younger siblings.......  sometimes for 8 to 10 hours a day because of work and commuting schedules.  By the time I was 10 years old, I was able to cook a meal, clean a house and care for up to 4 younger siblings at a time.  Don't get me wrong, we had an enormous amount of fun but it came at the cost of a carefree girlhood.  But my mother and father worked and I was the responsible one so it was what it was.  I have no regrets because it made ma a responsible, flexible and decisive person.  But it was...... sometimes overwhelming.  And I only had four to look out for at a time.  Imagine nineteen siblings with no end in sight.....

The good thing is that we had options.  We lived in a fairly urbanized area and we were able to interact with various characters in the neighborhood, organize impromptu baseball or marble tournaments and fairly well develop that "gift of discernment".  We knew which girls and boys were doing "the nasty"; who was using drugs or alcohol, .... basically as we settled into our routine in each city of our very frequent moves due to my father being in the military.  We had our own cohorts and almost separate lives from that of our parents.  We were able to essentially interact with the leaders of the local girls and boys club where we spent many, many  hours playing pool, cards, watching movies and just jiving around.  In doing that we discovered societal norms and incorporated them into our core values.  We found out what church bus was going to what church and chose to take the ones, on a rotating basis  that served the free potluck.  God's Word was important but so was the enchilada casserole, fried chicken, macaroni and cheese  and blueberry pie (smile).

No back to the Duggars.....  They had few options - especially the young girls.  Last night as I watched the interview.... three times, I noticed one overarching theme......  The need to protect Josh, the eldest of their children.  In a patriarchal home the father and subsequently the male children are very, very important. The girls are prettied up in the face and hair division (then covered from head to toe) , the boys are given "free reign" and wear what they want.   The girls work in the home, the boys play hard.  So back to the interview.....The mother Michelle, in her whispery, child-like voice, (Austen and Aubrey asked why she spoke that way), asserted that the girls did not even know what happened to them until the newspapers reveled the information .... they slept through the entire "fondling" ordeal on the many occasions that it occurred.  I wonder if anyone ever asked the girls about their recollection of the events or whether it was ever important enough for them to do so.  Another thing that came through was the forced crying on Michelle's part, and the father --- Jim Bob's constant round trip to the legalities of a possible lawsuit, who leaked the information and so forth.  They do not share power in this relationship.  

The two girls who will be interviewed tomorrow are the ones that have been married off and are now mothers themselves.  From the previews, both of them are humiliated ... one more than the other.  The one that seems the most upset has fingernails that appear to be eaten to the quick.  The one is very, very attractive and a bit more spunky.  One of the greatest tragedies of this episode is that neither of them can really fathom that they are not alone.  Neither of them can fathom that instead of being angry at who "outed" the information, they should be grateful that someone had the courage to expose this terrible episode of not only the molestation but the lack of empathy and respect for their feelings displayed by not only the community around them but by their parents as well.  Harboring such a terrible secret, why would the parents allow this type of program to go forth and why were they so isolated from others that their own spirit of discernment not able to develop?  

We don't know much about the "missing" family members in the parent's respective "trees".  They are not spoken about and I suspect that they are not of the same mind.  Don't get me wrong, a large family is a Blessing, I would not trade any of my experiences nor any of my siblings for anything in the world.  We fight, yes, but each of them have contributed so very much to the fabric of my life that I am eternally Grateful for the journey, however, in my growing up home --- we were not under "strict rule", we watched what we wanted, had friends, stayed out of trouble, went to church ---- and attended school with people of minds that were not like ours.  Our children are loaned to us as a gift,   we as parents are tasked with teaching, guiding and counselling.  When we indoctrinate, we take away the natural gifts .... one being discernment that God bestows upon us.  We assume that "we" know better and "we" are inherently better than the Will of God.  But we all mercifully pass away and we leave on this earth the fruits of our being, we should prepare them by polishing the diamond in the rough and showing off its many capabilities ---- male or female.

I am personally glad, for the children's sake, that this program is coming to a close.  They need to heal.  We should not showcase our children until the job is finished, they need the room to grow outside of the scrutiny of the "madding crowd" who bring with them their own baggage for scrutiny.  I hope that the Duggar parents seek a measure of humility and true guidance of the full love of the Lord.  I also pray that Josh gets the help that he will need and the counselling that he will need.  Normal adolescent boys of 15 don't view their 5 year old sister as a possible sexual mate, this is often a "learned" response.  The "devil" didn't make him do it.....  There is a "chip" missing somewhere and the fact that he has young children concerns me.  

Psalm 127:3Good News Translation (GNT)

3 Children are a gift from the Lord;
    they are a real blessing.

status_message:
Good Tuesday Afternoon!

The High Cost of Victimhood

Yesterday, I was appalled to read in a comment a little rant from someone who should know better.  He claimed that the problems in Baltimore were as a result of the "white police state" and that Baltimore is now "reaping what was sowed".  Apparently this was a stab at the so-called "white establishment" who  "really runs" Baltimore or any other city in which a policeman/woman has either been involved with or the direct cause of the death of a black man.  This same tone was repeated over and over by one news station after another parading a number of people Black and White with their own version of "what is wrong"  with life in the inner city and why Black men are killing each other in greater numbers than you can even imagine.  

The enduring theme is that "someone is making them do it", and if just a little more money, just a little more mentoring  or just a little more of this or that or a little less police interference or ….   WALLAH! Things will change.  Crime will go down , everyone will be self-actualized and life will be good…….   Another very preposterous suggestion this morning was that we begin to pay money to the people NOT to kill each other or behave badly.  All of these suggestions and the anecdotes to bad behavior is about as effective as a vaccine for the common cold.  Sometimes the answers we seek are the ones we do not want to hear because they are painful.  

Many of us can remember the first class of Psychology, a required course for University studies.  One of the first explanations for human behavior was explained by "Maslow's Hierarchy of Needs".    Maslow (1943) stated that people are motivated to achieve certain needs. When one need is fulfilled a person seeks to fulfil the next one, and so on.    Let me review this model:

1.  Biological and Physiological needs - air, food, drink, shelter, warmth, sex, sleep.
2.  Safety needs - protection from elements, security, order, law, stability, freedom from fear.
3. Love and belongingness needs - friendship, intimacy, affection and love, - from work group, family, friends, romantic relationships.
4. Esteem needs - achievement, mastery, independence, status, dominance, prestige, self-respect, respect from others.
5. Self-Actualization needs - realizing personal potential, self-fulfillment, seeking personal growth and peak experiences.

When I watch the interviews, the common theme among the apologists and those seeking fame, fortune and other personal political and monetary elevation through their suggestions for the madness engulfing the inner city, is to move directly to "building esteem or elevating personal growth" of the Black male who, for some reason is suffering from the after-effects of slavery, Jim Crow, and the oppression of "DA" Man. 

This is all total "poppycock".

A child raised without the stability of a home, which often necessitates more than a single parent struggling to survive; without the benefits of good nutrition; safety and protection from abuse (either physical or sexual);  without the benefits of a warm environment of friendship, kinship, and other formal or informal relationships that foster a feeling of warmth and acceptance will have a "damaged" psyche.  Granted, there are always exceptions to this rule, some personalities are so phlegmatic or needy that they naturally don't respond to these entreaties but this is more the exception than the rule.  And the opposite is true also.  You might find a success story here and there that will illustrate the child raised in extreme deprivation that will respond positively to "self-actualization" types of remedies, but I assert that the is not going to work over large swathes of the population.

The Corner is a 2000 HBO drama television miniseries based on the true story" The Corner: A Year in the Life of an Inner-City Neighborhood" by David Simon and Ed Burns and adapted for television by Simon and David Mills. It premiered on premium cable network HBO in the United States on April 16, 2000, and concluded its six-part run on May 21, 2000. 

Guess what city the story highlighted?  None other than Baltimore.  The location?  The same as the riots. The Corner tells the story the life of a family living in poverty amid the open-air drug markets of West Baltimore. "The corner" is at the junction of West Fayette Street and North Monroe Street.  Fifteen years ago and nothing changed for the better and much for the worse.
It centers mostly around the lives of Gary McCullough (he had dreams of a good life but dropped out of college and gradually became a drug addict), his ex-wife Fran Boyd, also an addict, and their son DeAndre McCullough, a high school student who begins to sell drugs.  It was a difficult program to watch and I did one time, I just could not subject myself to a second round.  I suppose the saddest creature in the book was Gary, who tried his very best but had no foundation to support his dreams of a "better life".  The rest of the characters never had a chance because their lives were based on such shaky ground,  however, I understand that the mother, Fran, found her way out.   

DeAndre finally succumbed to drug addiction even after many, many chances and much money thrown at his problems.  DeAndre went clean for a number of years and even had a minor role The Wire. However, on August 1, 2012, he was found dead at the age of 35, from a drug overdose.  The money, fame and overtures for self-actualization will not work when the soul is empty.

So what is the high cost of opportunistic political leadership, throwing money at self-actualization types of training as stupid ad elitist as  the  "boneheaded" St. Paul school district which began a contractual relationship with the Pacific Educational Group, a San Francisco-based organization that tries to help public schools deal with achievement and disciplinary issues involving black students. ----- they spent over two million dollars in 5 years when they could have had classes in parenting, started athletic programs, and community groups for much less.    

And what was the result of this asinine training in St. Paul?   Becky McQueen, an educator at St. Paul's Harding High School, was beaten around the head and ears by strong high-school basketball players after trying to stop a fight.  The "kid" was only sent home for a couple of days, after all she is just a "white lady" and probably deserved it because of slavery or Jim Crow or ….
And the targeting of Ms. McQueen continued…. "Yet another student who repeatedly drops into her class has hit kids and cursed at an aide, once telling McQueen he would "fry" her ass. She tried to make a joke of it — 'Ooh, I could use a little weight loss.' Her students interjected: 'No, that means he's gonna kill you.'"  I guess her "white self" did not know the thug lingo.
McQueen now has her students use a secret knock on the classroom door, so she will know who to allow in.

So, that is the real cost, young black people who do not know the boundaries of civilized society will be released into a society that will show them in quick fashion that they will not be as tolerant.  Lest you  think that this is an unusual situation, my friend was pinched on the breast by an 11th grader she was teaching.  The school refused to hear it, but called a meeting with the father after a repeated incident where he tried to grope her.  The father's response to my friend?  "You sure are one pretty white woman, he couldn't help himself".  

Wanna bet the kid will pay a price in the future?  Pay now or pay later.  Equality means paying the "equal " price for your goods, for your life, for your actions.  No more excuses for bad behavior.  I suppose the posting I wrote about at the beginning of this story was correct, we are "reaping what we have sowed".  And the "chickens"  are coming home to roost…….. they are in the "killing fields" of West Baltimore, Chicago, New York and most major cities where over the past 35 years in America, an estimated 324,000 blacks have been killed at the hands of fellow blacks, proving "racist" white cops are the least of their worries; Minority women constitute only about 13% of the female population (age 15-44) in the United States, but they underwent approximately 36% of the abortions. On average, 1,876 black babies are aborted every day in the United States;  and "more than 72 percent of children in the African-American community are born out of wedlock."

Yes…. The "chickens are coming home to roost"……. They are killing each other and rioting to please the very people who should be helping them……. With the truth……. That change and betterment will begin from within and until this fact is digested, there will be a high price to pay…. A very high one  especially when the killing fields spread their territory.... the gated communities in which they formulate their theories and the private schools where they protect their young.  It's  coming.

status_message:
Good Thursday Morning!

 Easter, Christmas, weddings or funerals.

Last week I received an article claiming that although the "U.S. has a reputation for being exceptionally religious—and it is true that, historically speaking, churchgoing has played an outsized role in American identity. Still, millions of Americans have little to no connection to local congregations."

Although I could write about a plethora of other issues, this one most directly speaks to the changing culture of American society.  Currently, 38 percent of adults have not attended a church service, except for a holiday or special occasion, at any time within the past six months."Unchurched adults include "dechurched"—that is, those who used to attend regularly but have not attended at all in the past six months—and "never churched"—meaning they have never in their lives regularly attended a church.  The article goes on to say:

While San Francisco is number one overall when it comes to churchless residents, it ranks sixth on the never-churched list (14%), outpaced by:

.  West Palm Beach-Ft. Pierce, FL (17%)
.  Santa Barbara-Santa Maria-San Luis Obispo, CA (16%)
.  New York, NY (15%)
.  Harlingen-Weslaco-Brownsville-McAllen, TX (15%)
.  Chico-Redding, CA (15%)
http://cities.barna.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/04/bu-042215-ig-6.jpg

The first entry, "West Palm Beach-Ft. Pierce, FL" is exactly where I live. After doing some research I found out that a 2008 Gallup poll comparing belief in God among U.S. regions found that only 59% of residents in the Western United States believe in a god, compared to 80% in the East, 83% in the Midwest, and 86% in the South.  The poll also showed that Oregon ranked as the state with the highest percentage of residents identifying with "No religion, Atheist, or Agnostic", at 24.6%.

In addition, according to a Pew report. the proportion of Jews who say they have no religion and are Jewish only on the basis of ancestry, ethnicity or culture is growing rapidly, and two-thirds of them are not raising their children Jewish at all.Among Jewish denominations, the Reform movement remains the largest: 35 percent of respondents identified as Reform, according to the Pew study. The second-largest group is Jews of no denomination (30 percent), followed by Conservative (18 percent) and Orthodox (10 percent).

So..... what does this mean? In a spiritual realm. agree or disagree with me if you like, people seem meaner, lost and smaller.  Unfortunately for those who believe that God is some "made up fairytale in the sky",most human beings find the world a bit too big and too complicated to rely upon their own understanding and will seek other, perhaps more destructive means, of coping with hurt, pain , betrayal, loss or bewilderment. Among our youth, we have read reports of them running away from perfectly comfortable middle class homes to go to the barren desert and fight against these wonderful "creature comforts" to fight against their own country... and their own seeming great advantages.  Although these occurrences are relatively rare,  the movement towards the legalization of drugs and the disproportionate level of disaffection with seemingly common "rules" of society is not.  The reliance upon prescription drugs to make us "happy" and able to "cope" is another boondoggle. Adults who used to "say a little prayer" are now reaching for the Xanax.

Among other things, the reliance upon the belief of a "higher being" provides us with the framework for morality, for decency, for treating others.  They provide the "rules" for an orderly, respectful and 'livable" society.  When these walls break down, we witness Baltimore, where the mayor had no concept of personal property, no regard for safety, no wisdom to know the limits of a population so far from the center of society that they could not control the urges to destroy their OWN backyard, shelter and safety.   

Human beings are NOT inherently moral creatures.  They are intelligent, but not inherently moral. We are not inherently brave, not inherently unselfish.  Being a Christian, I understand the evils of the world. We all give in to sin, we all fall, and we all fail. 
Children are good examples. They have not yet defined their beliefs and act on nature rather than what is right. Children are taught to act a certain manner, it is not a natural state that a child  comes into the world knowing what is right and wrong; just as an animal does not have a bit of compassion for a member of its own species, it thinks of the other as a competitor and not as a friend. 

Man/Woman by nature does not choose to be moral, we would rather choose to run around and sleep with every woman/man/boy/girl/baby or whatever before settling with a partner. We would rather murder our rival than choose to love him its easier. We would prefer lying than to tell the truth it's easier and will satisfy many more people....... make us popular. BUT religion tells us to do otherwise. It tells us to be patient and faithful, withholding our bodies from giving in. It tells us to not only love our enemies but care for them, go the extra mile to change their lives. It tells us to defeat the evil within and become better than good but perfect... or at least try.

Without the framework, how would our laws come into being?  We are here in time for what amounts to a 'blink of an eye", how could we consider the fashioning of laws based upon the 10 Commandments which would not exist without religiosity.

But, Angela, more people have died in the name of religion than not.... right?  Don't know, what I do know is that in the absence of religion there would be some type of ideology that would have created the same wars, the same deaths and probably much more.  The deaths under Communism and socialism are legion, regardless of the current amorous flirtation going on with these utopian ideals.  

We can become disillusioned by the religious leader, the grasping/greedy proselytizer who exploits the sadness and poverty (either in spirit or wealth) of his congregation and implores them to provide him with a 65 million dollar jet and Rolls Royces and other luxury play-toys.  The stylish "preacher-dudes" who possess personal  lifestyles dirtier than any prostitute, or criminal flashes on every billboard, enticing you with promises of sexual discussions from the pulpit.  On a smaller note, we get saddened when the head of the marriage initiative has an affair with the head of the Christian school. We feel betrayed and say to ourselves "religion is full of hypocrites".  Nope it is just full of people, just like you and me.... satisfying their immediate and profane wants, needs and desires.....  

But these are just the messengers and they are purposefully flawed to illustrate that man will fall short, very short of the glory and perfection..... and we love the messenger anyways.  He/she is one of us.

The politician (especially those running for President) will likely have to acknowledge, however, in this next election that the "evangelical" vote might not be enough to get them over the "hump".  People sometimes confuse the messenger with the message, so they are not receptive to heavy doctrine.  But never give up, even the "Easter, Christmas, weddings or funerals" people - (change the holiday terminology for each religion), inherently understand that values, morality and the survival of society will depend upon the constancy of the "guiding hand" that moves us towards what is right and away from what is truly destructive both personally and nationwide.

Have a great day!

status_message:
Good Tuesday Evening

Her Eyes are Watching Duke Lacrosse....

The Maryland state's attorney whose activist comments and alleged conflicts of interest have become a central part of the Freddie Gray case, appeared on stage at a Prince concert Sunday as the musician performed a protest song about Gray and the recent unrest in Baltimore.

Marilyn Mosby and her husband Nick Mosby, a Baltimore city councilman, sat on a couch on stage during Prince's "Rally 4 Peace" benefit concert, according to the Baltimore Sun.  

So what was said at this "get together"?

"Nobody got in nobody's way, so I guess you could say it was a good day, at least a little better than the day in Baltimore. Does anybody hear us pray, for Michael Brown or Freddie Gray? Peace is more than the absence of a war," the song goes.

"If there ain't no justice than there ain't no peace," it continues.

"The system is broken," Prince told the audience, according to the Sun. "It's going to take the young people to fix it this time. We need new ideas, new life."

While Mosby did not speak to the audience during the concert, her appearance comes just two days after the cops in the case filed motions of dismissal and recusal. The officers claim that Mosby has several personal, political and professional conflicts of interest and that she should remove herself from the case and allow a special prosecutor to take over.

According to the Sun, Mosby's husband gave her the tickets for the concert as a Mother's Day gift.

Even before appearing on stage with Prince Sunday, Mosby has been accused of making statements that were seen as prejudiced against the criminal justice system.

"I heard your call for 'no justice, no peace,'" Mosby said when she announced charges against the officers.

Kind of interesting words for a prosecutor, now....... does it sound "unbiased to you?"

In the infamous Duke lacrosse case, there was no rape or kidnapping and the real scandal was the baseless prosecution by Mike Nifong, an opportunistic white man then serving by appointment as district attorney in Durham, North Carolina and willing to pander to black voters in a Democrat primary in order to win election and keep his job, the prosecution of six Baltimore police officers by Marilyn Mosby, a young black female who became Baltimore state attorney earlier this year after winning a Democrat primary against a white male incumbent last year and the wife of Baltimore councilman Nick Mosby, seemed to be an egregious abuse of power by a politically motivated person.

Meanwhile........Richard Fletcher was attacked by nearly 50 teens in broad daylight on April 22, after he intervened when two girls began fighting on his truck. Dundalk sits on the edge of Baltimore, and many of the teenagers are believed to be students at Baltimore Community High School.

The gruesome beating left Fletcher with extensive injuries and a medical bill expected to exceed $200,000. He suffered broken eye sockets, a broken nose, broken ribs and bleeding on the brain.

New cell phone video of the attack shows dozens of teens kicking, punching, and stomping Fletcher as he lay motionless in the middle of the street.

Will he get the "justice or peace" that Mosby is speaking of?  Probably not.

Baltimore's "plucky young state's attorney" Marilyn Mosby reportedly sent a text message to her mother.

"Heads up," Mosby wrote. "National media is focusing on me."

"You'll be all right," Linda Thompson, a retired Baltimore police officer, replied.

We will see.... but what about the rest of Baltimore..... will it be "all right" as well?  BTW, only three of Fletcher's attackers have been arrested so far.

status_message:
Good Sunday Morning and Happy Mother's Day!

Why We Deserve Better Leadership in America.

The object of life is not to be on the side of the majority, but to escape finding oneself in the ranks of the insane.
Marcus Aurelius

For the last few days, as I navigated a very busy schedule, I did not write but I did THINK and think deeply about the fiasco that we have found ourselves in.  So, you ask, what fiasco?  The first is the inability to think rationally as adults.  Everything in political life now rests upon two questions:  "Do you like me? " and if the answer is "yes".... then the next question is:
 
"Why, is it because I am cute/funny/pretty/handsome?"  followed by "What can you do FOR me now?"  

If the answer to the aforementioned question happens to be "no", then the next question willy by "Why, is it because:

I am fat/skinny/Black/White/Asian/Latin/woman/man/ugly/too pretty for you/gay/straight/lesbian/transgender/tall or short?  And this is followed by "What can I DO TO you now?"

Because in an entitlement society, everyone "deserves" to be liked and you must be punished for NOT liking a person because,after all, everyone DESERVES LOVE AND AFFECTION.  And if you don't love me, you are racist, ______ ophobic (fill in the blank), and deserving of your and 2000 or more of your "closest allies" at-will" persecution, silencing and even death.  AND because this is your right, (to be liked), you are able to carry out any and all offenses with the silent nod of the political class, who will wholeheartedly play upon the soft under-belly of resentment from not being liked by telling you that as you loot, shoot and burn down neighborhoods...... "your time has come".  You will vote for these types and give them high approvals because, for the most part, the IQ slips 50 points down in a "group"..... it does not climb ... in other words two heads may be greater than one but by the third head the trio becomes one big dunce.  As you add more to the group, the problem gets exponentially worse, especially with bad or nonexistent leadership.  

So, now in "group think" emotionally charged environment we see the the everlasting "polls"....  and these polls show you what the "majority" of ______ are thinking.  This is so that you.... John/Jane Doe Citizen can "fall in line" with the "majority", no matter how idiotic or nonsensical the thinking and actions of the "majority" can and will be.  Let me give you some examples: 

.  African-Americans and Latinos believe the police do target minorities (69 percent and 54 percent, respectively). Fewer than a third of whites feel that way (29 percent).  What does this mean?  Does it mean that "cops hate minorities"? Ummmm... no.  It means that it is unusual that your average person can see things from anything outside of their own experiences.  Of course, no one has it worse than YOU because YOU can only feel your own experiences.... not the other guy's.  Also, if your experiences are fraught with negative incidents, then YOU feel the brunt of the attention, not the positive aspects.  Last night two policemen in Hattiesburg, Mississippi stopped a Hyundai vehicle carrying three suspects, shots were fired by "one individual" from the vehicle.  The result is that on this Mother's Day..... two mothers will be in gut wrenching anguish as they mourn the loss of their LAW ABIDING sons they gave birth to just a little over two short decades ago.  One of the arresting officers is just two years older than my "big baby".  I am sure that if you spoke with THESE mothers, you would be able to glean from them a moment by moment account of the first moments of their now deceased baby boy's first moments on this earth.  these are the first Hattiesburg officers to die in the line of duty in 30 years.

Hattiesburg resident Tamika Mills was quoted by The Clarion-Ledger as saying some bystanders came upon the officers on the ground, and that one of the officers asked "… 'Am I dying? I know I'm dying. Just hand me my walkie-talkie,'"

A true hero.....  doing his job.  

.  Last week, a very inexperienced prosecutor, charged 6 policemen/women with a number of charges, after which she exhorted the crowd with, among other things "As young people, our time is now," to a screaming, fawning crowd moments before she giddily told HER mommie that the major news outlets were watching and her proud mommie replied that  "The world's her stage right now, and she's shining like a star."  I am happy for Mosby's mother, her daughter's "rise to the stars" will come at the expense of the destruction of 6 lives because of raw, naked ambition.  But that's besides the point.  And what of the "mom and pop" businesses, wig shops, hair-dressing salons, drug-stores, auto-body shops, and the other various and sundry businesses now burned to the ground as the looters and shooters who had not a pot to pee in nor the window to throw it out of made them all one in the same?  Well, just another milky way step on the road to fame for the leadership of Baltimore who will play the "you hate me 'cause I'm black card" as they too hitch their rusty chain to the "star" of race and victim politics.

We deserve better in America, not just for ourselves but for future generations.  As we mothers and fathers raise our progeny, we should allow them to "walk a mile" in the other man's or woman's shoes.  People don't emerge from the birth canal wearing a policeman's uniform.  it is a profession and in this profession you will have good and bad people.  It is incumbent upon the stronger minds and intellects to make sure that we project the correct messages, understanding that if you target one group, eventually, the majority - with their combined mob insanity will eventually turn on YOU.  

We deserve better in America than voting "identity" politics, we don't "hate women" because we can't vote for Hillary Clinton.  We just hate the drama, we just hate the deceit, we just think that these last few years have done more to tear us apart than bring us together.  We just don't believe that she is a good leader.

Finally, we deserve better in America than demagogues who seek anarchy by destroying the very men and women who hold back the tide of madness, larceny and destruction.  We know that our personal tendency is towards cowardice and it is those brave one percent among us that keep us from the shackles of bondage to other humans who hold within themselves very dark hearts.  The average police person, military, fireman and other public servant will embody the spine and backbone that too many of us lack and shame on those who say differently.

We deserve better in America, to keep America great.

status_message:
Five Surprising Facts About Mother's Day

1. It was founded for mourning women to remember fallen soldiers and work for peace. And when the holiday went commercial, its greatest champion, Anna Jarvis, gave everything to fight it, dying penniless and broken in a sanitarium.

2.   It all started in the 1850s, when West Virginia women's organizer Ann Reeves Jarvis—Anna's mother—held Mother's Day work clubs to improve sanitary conditions and try to lower infant mortality by fighting disease and curbing milk contamination, according to historian Katharine Antolini of West Virginia Wesleyan College. The groups also tended wounded soldiers from both sides during the U.S. Civil War from 1861 to 1865.

3.  Anna Jarvis never had children of her own, but the 1905 death of her own mother inspired her to organize the first Mother's Day observances in 1908.

4.  Largely through Jarvis's efforts, Mother's Day came to be observed in a growing number of cities and states until U.S. President Woodrow Wilson officially set aside the second Sunday in May in 1914 for the holiday. "It wasn't to celebrate all mothers. It was to celebrate the best mother you've ever known—your mother—as a son or a daughter." That's why Jarvis stressed the singular "Mother's Day," rather than the plural "Mothers' Day,"

5.  The holiday Anna Jarvis launched has spread around much of the world, though it's celebrated with varying enthusiasm, in various ways, and on various days—though more often than not on the second Sunday in May.

In much of the Arab world, Mother's Day is on March 21, which happens to loosely coincide with the start of spring. In Panama the day is celebrated on December 8, when the Catholic Church honors perhaps the most famous of mothers, the Virgin Mary. In Thailand mothers are honored on August 12, the birthday of Queen Sirikit, who has reigned since 1956 and is considered by many to be a mother to all Thais.

Britain's centuries-old Mothering Sunday, the fourth Sunday of the Christian period of Lent, began as a spring Sunday designated for people to visit their area's main cathedral, or mother church, rather than their local parish.

Mothering Sunday church travel led to family reunions, which in turn led to Britain's version of Mother's Day.

http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2014/05/140508-mothers-day-nation-gifts-facts-culture-moms/

THE POLICE OFFICER HAS DIED.

The plainclothes New York police officer who was shot in the face as he approached an armed man on a Queens street died from his injuries on Monday, the police commissioner, William J. Bratton, said.

The officer, Brian Moore, 25, had been in critical condition at Jamaica Hospital Medical Center since Saturday evening when fellow officers rushed him to the emergency room from the residential street where the shooting occurred.

"I did not know this officer in person in life; I've only come to know him in death," Mr. Bratton said to reporters outside the hospital.

Mr. Bratton called Officer Moore "an extraordinary young man" and said his death was "a great loss to this profession and to this city."

Before the ambulance carrying Office Moore's body left the hospital, distraught relatives placed their hands on it with hundreds of officers looking on.

Demetrius Blackwell, 35, was arraigned in Queens County Criminal Court on Sunday in the shooting of an officer.
