status_message:
Good Sunday Morning!

Before or after the Hillary Tsunami....

What an "Action Packed" Week Ahead!

>Today will mark the first day of "Hillary Rising".  The mystery is over.  Her theme? Will center on boosting economic security for the middle class and expanding opportunities for working families, while casting the former senator and secretary of state as a "tenacious fighter" able to get results, two senior advisers said Saturday.

We will get a chance to hear her many accents, and trials as well as tribulations.  Because she always feels "no ways tard".  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DGDm4jkDbGQ

President Barack Obama feels: "I think she would be an excellent president."

>Sen. Marco Rubio getting his big moment on Monday at just about the same time Hillary Clinton dominates the news cycle.  Probably pretty good luck for him.  The ability to build a "stealth" momentum might benefit him better than the continual attacks met by Rand Paul last week.  

So my question is:  Was it better to come before the tsunami or after?

Last week the press went in a couple directions regarding Rand Paul.  The first was to paint him with one stroke of the brush as "strange".  Pictures of him sitting half dressed in a suit from the waist up and shorts from the waist down, or looking confused on the metro.....  did nothing to bolster his "I'm just like you" image that was probably hoped for.......  Instead these pics were run without caption.  Then...... the article entitled "What Makes Rand Paul Strange"  which had nothing to do with his personality only his views on childhood vaccinations.  AND then, instead of analyzing the man's stance with the eye to the fact that he has many people who sympathize with his views.....  the author also brands him as: "By not going that extra philosophical mile — and adding junk science to the mix — Paul comes off as merely weird.."

Then, not to be outdone according to the the Atlantic posits that  he is "wacky"  but they mean it in a "loving way":

 "Rand Paul has some extreme—even wacky—views on issues that media professionals tend not to understand or care about, like monetary policy, or have discounted as an inescapable feature of the American political landscape, like guns. But because Paul deviates from what's seen as conservative orthodoxy on foreign policy, drugs, and policing, he benefits from a perception that his views are new, different, interesting, and potentially even appealing across party lines".

And don't forget that he is also "mean to girls" as they point back to an interview in which: "He famously rebuked CNBC host Kelly Evans, saying:  "You have taken an interview and made an interview into something where we got no useful information because you were argumentative and you started out with so many prepositions (sic) that were incorrect."

He was right, in his assessment.

Oh boy......  the article proclaiming him weird and strange also made mention of his propensity to be mean to girls also....  This will also be brought out by the Hillary machine which has already started with an unrecognizable photograph of Chelsea Clinton on the cove of Elle magazine.   Chelsea Clinton talks to ELLE regarding her perfect baby, perfect marriage and the need for a woman in the White House.In a photo entitled "Lookin' good, girl!"  the magazine states in the best 1950's "girl talk"  fashion:

 " The new mom, 34, showed off her small frame in skinny jeans and a blue T-shirt. The former first daughter also strapped on brown cowboy boots and gave a glance of her gorgeous wedding band."

Read more: http://www.usmagazine.com/celebrity-news/news/chelsea-clinton-wears-skinny-jeans-post-baby-looks-amazing-photo-2015271#ixzz3X5xzGfCU 

Mind you, the article was supposed to speak about shattering the glass ceiling and putting a woman in the White House .... in a leadership role.  How fortunate the flexibility of this campaign (smile).  Notice Hillary was not wearing the skinny jeans.

So the week before, Ted Cruz was deemed "unelectable", then Rand Paul was determined to be "strange, wacky and weird", Rubio will have his own theme tomorrow (and if you know the press it won't be flattering), but I ask you.......  What do you think Hillary Rodham Clinton's theme will be?

status_message:
Good Tuesday Evening!

It Was Never About YOUR Freedom....... Silly boys and girls!

The Equal Protection Clause of the 14th amendment of the U.S. Constitution prohibits states from denying any person within its jurisdiction the equal protection of the laws. See U.S. Const. amend. XIV. In other words, the laws of a state must treat an individual in the same manner as others in similar conditions and circumstances.  

The equal protection clause is not intended to provide "equality" among individuals or classes but only "equal application" of the laws. 

Soooooo......On the one hand:

A Colorado judge today determined that a Lakewood bakery unlawfully discriminated against a gay couple by refusing to sell them a wedding cake.

David Mullins and Charlie Craig visited Masterpiece Cakeshop last year, with Craig's mother, to order a cake for their upcoming wedding reception. Mullins and Craig planned to marry in Massachusetts and then celebrate with family and friends back home in Colorado. Masterpiece owner Jack Phillips informed them that because of his religious beliefs the store's policy was to deny service to customers who wished to order baked goods to celebrate a same-sex couple's wedding.

"Being denied service by Masterpiece Cakeshop was offensive and dehumanizing especially in the midst of arranging what should be a joyful family celebration," said Mullins. "No one should fear being turned away from a public business because of who they are. We are grateful to have the support of our community and our state, and we hope that today's decision will help ensure that no one else will experience this kind of discrimination again in Colorado."http://aclu-co.org/court-rules-bakery-illegally-discriminated-against-gay-couple/

But then on the other hand:

A Denver bakery has found itself at the center of an LGBT rights controversy. But this isn't about another bakery refusing to fulfill an order for a same-sex wedding. Instead, Azucar Bakery in Denver is the subject of a Colorado civil rights investigation for declining to decorate a cake with an anti-gay message.

A customer, identified as Bill Jack, told reporters that he believes Azucar Bakery "discriminated" against him "based on my creed," which is Christian. He filed a complaint with the Colorado Civil Rights Division some time last year, though according to his statement to reporters, Jack said he wouldn't comment on the specifics of the complaint. But the baker in question did.
Jack walked into Azucar Bakery last March and asked for two cakes, both in the shape of Bibles. That wasn't a problem for Marjorie Silva, the bakery's owner. It was what Jack wanted her to write on the cake: Anti-gay phrases including "God hates gays" and an image of two men holding hands, covered in a big, red "X."
"It's unfair that he's accusing me of discriminating when I think he was the one that is discriminating," Silva told NBC affiliate KUSA. She said she refused to inscribe the cakes with the requested messages and soon after received notice from the state's Department of Regulatory Agencies that she was the subject of a religious discrimination complaint.http://www.washingtonpost.com/news/post-nation/wp/2015/01/22/this-colorado-baker-refused-to-put-an-anti-gay-message-on-cakes-now-she-is-facing-a-civil-rights-complaint/

So, we know how the first case ended...... what about the second?

Using the commission's logic – if a Christian baker is forced to violate his beliefs, shouldn't all bakers be forced to violate theirs, too?

Absolutely not, says the Colorado Civil Rights Commission.
It ruled that Azucar did not discriminate against Jack based on his creed. It argued that the bakery refused to make the cakes because of the "derogatory language and imagery," The Denver Channel reported. 
http://www.foxnews.com/opinion/2015/04/07/colorado-double-standard-bakers-should-not-be-forced-to-make-anti-gay-cakes/

So:

If the owner of Azucar Bakery can run her business according to her beliefs – why can't the owner of the Masterpiece Cakeshop? Is equal protection under the law now "favored" protection under the law?

status_message:
Martin Luther King Jr. was an American Baptist minister, activist, humanitarian, and leader in the African-American Civil Rights Movement. Wikipedia

Born: January 15, 1929, Atlanta, GA
Spouse: Coretta Scott King (m. 1953–1968)
Assassinated: April 4, 1968, Memphis, TN

King had arrived in Tennessee on Wednesday, 3 April to prepare for a march the following Monday on behalf of striking Memphis sanitation workers. As he prepared to leave the Lorraine Motel for a dinner at the home of Memphis minister Samuel ''Billy'' Kyles, King stepped out onto the balcony of room 306 to speak with Southern Christian Leadership Conference (SCLC) colleagues standing in the parking area below. An assassin ﬁred a single shot that caused severe wounds to the lower right side of his face. SCLC aides rushed to him, and Ralph Abernathy cradled King's head. Others on the balcony pointed across the street toward the rear of a boarding house on South Main Street where the shot seemed to have originated. An ambulance rushed King to St. Joseph's Hospital, where doctors pronounced him dead at 7:05 P.M. 

President Lyndon B. Johnson called for a national day of mourning to be observed on 7 April. In the following days, public libraries, museums, schools, and businesses were closed, and the Academy Awards ceremony and numerous sporting events were postponed. On 8 April King's widow, Coretta Scott King, and other family members joined thousands of participants in a march in Memphis honoring King and supporting the sanitation workers. King's funeral service was held the following day in Atlanta at Ebenezer Baptist Church. It was attended by many of the nation's political and civil rights leaders, including Jacqueline Kennedy, Vice President Hubert Humphrey, and Ralph Bunche. Morehouse College President Benjamin Mays delivered the eulogy, predicting that King ''would probably say that, if death had to come, I am sure there was no greater cause to die for than ﬁghting to get a just wage for garbage collectors'' (Mays, 9 April 1968). Over 100,000 mourners followed two mules pulling King's cofﬁn through the streets of Atlanta. After another ceremony on the Morehouse campus, King's body was initially interred at South-View Cemetery. Eventually, it was moved to a crypt next to the Ebenezer Church at the King Center, an institution founded by King's widow. 

Shortly after the assassination, a policeman discovered a bundle containing a 30.06 Remington riﬂe next door to the boarding house. The largest investigation in Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) history led its agents to an apartment in Atlanta. Fingerprints uncovered in the apartment matched those of James Earl Ray, a fugitive who had escaped from a Missouri prison in April 1967. FBI agents and police in Memphis produced further evidence that Ray had registered on 4 April at the South Main Street roominghouse and that he had taken a second-ﬂoor room near a common bathroom with a view of the Lorraine Motel. 

The identiﬁcation of Ray as a suspect led to an international manhunt. On 19 July 1968, Ray was extradited to the United States from Britain to stand trial. In a plea bargain, Tennessee prosecutors agreed in March 1969 to forgo seeking the death penalty when Ray pled guilty to murder charges. The circumstances leading to the plea later became a source of controversy, when Ray recanted his confession soon after being sentenced to a 99-year term in prison. 

During the years following King's assassination, doubts about the adequacy of the case against Ray were fueled by revelations of the extensive surveillance of King by the FBI and other government agencies. Beginning in 1976, the House Select Committee on Assassinations, chaired by Representative Louis Stokes, re-examined the evidence concerning King's assassination, as well as that of President John F. Kennedy. The committee's ﬁnal report suggested that Ray may have had co-conspirators. The report nonetheless concluded that there was no convincing evidence of government complicity in King's assassination. 

After recanting his guilty plea, Ray continued to maintain his innocence, claiming to have been framed by a gun-smuggler he knew as ''Raoul.'' In 1993 Ray's lawyer, William F. Pepper, sought to build popular support to reopen Ray's case by staging a televised mock trial of Ray in which the ''jury'' found him not guilty. In 1997 members of King's family publicly supported Ray's appeal for a new trial, and King's son Dexter Scott King supported Ray's claims innocence during a televised prison encounter. Despite this support Tennessee authorities refused to reopen the case, and Ray died in prison on 23 April 1998.

Even after Ray's death, conspiracy allegations continued to surface. In 1999, on behalf of King's widow and children, Pepper won a token civil verdict of wrongful death against Lloyd Jowers, owner of Jim's Grill, a restaurant across the street from the Lorraine Motel. Although the trial produced considerable testimony that contradicted the original case against Ray, the Justice Department announced in 2000 that its own internal investigation, launched in 1998 at the King family's request, had failed to ﬁnd sufﬁcient evidence to warrant a further investigation.

status_message:
Maya Angelou was an American author, poet, dancer, actress, and singer. She published seven autobiographies, three books of essays, and several books of poetry, and was credited with a list of plays, ... Wikipedia
Born: April 4, 1928, St. Louis, MO
Died: May 28, 2014, Winston-Salem, NC

Phenomenal Woman Poem by Maya Angelou

Pretty women wonder where my secret lies.
I'm not cute or built to suit a fashion model's size
But when I start to tell them,
They think I'm telling lies.
I say,
It's in the reach of my arms
The span of my hips,
The stride of my step,
The curl of my lips.
I'm a woman
Phenomenally.
Phenomenal woman,
That's me.

I walk into a room
Just as cool as you please,
And to a man,
The fellows stand or
Fall down on their knees.
Then they swarm around me,
A hive of honey bees.
I say,
It's the fire in my eyes,
And the flash of my teeth,
The swing in my waist,
And the joy in my feet.
I'm a woman
Phenomenally.
Phenomenal woman,
That's me.

Men themselves have wondered
What they see in me.
They try so much
But they can't touch
My inner mystery.
When I try to show them
They say they still can't see.
I say,
It's in the arch of my back,
The sun of my smile,
The ride of my breasts,
The grace of my style.
I'm a woman

Phenomenally.
Phenomenal woman,
That's me.

Now you understand
Just why my head's not bowed.
I don't shout or jump about
Or have to talk real loud.
When you see me passing
It ought to make you proud.
I say,
It's in the click of my heels,
The bend of my hair,
the palm of my hand,
The need of my care,
'Cause I'm a woman
Phenomenally.
Phenomenal woman,
That's me. 
Maya Angelou

Last night we went to a production of the Stations of the Cross by our church in Fort Lauderdale.  It was well done as most everything they do. On this day, the Blessed Virgin Mary as Our Lady of Sorrows is assigned the title Our Lady of Solitude, referring to her solace and grief at the death of her son Jesus.

Black Saturday, or Easter Eve,and called "Joyous Saturday" or "the Saturday of Light" among Coptic Christians, is the day after Good Friday. It is the day before Easter and the last day of Holy Week in which Christians prepare for Easter. It commemorates the day that Jesus Christ's body lay in the tomb and the Harrowing of Hell.Wikipedia

status_message:
Good Friday Morning!

The Mob...

According to the accounts in the Gospels, the Temple Guards, guided by Jesus' disciple Judas Iscariot, arrested Jesus in the Garden of Gethsemane. Judas received money (30 pieces of silver)  for betraying Jesus and told the guards that whomever he kisses is the one they are to arrest. Following his arrest, Jesus was brought to the house of Annas, the father-in-law of the high priest,Caiaphas. There he was interrogated with little result.

 Conflicting testimony against Jesus was brought forth by many witnesses, to which Jesus answered nothing. Finally the high priest adjured Jesus to respond under solemn oath, saying "I ask you, by the Living God, to tell us, are you the Anointed One, the Son of God?" Jesus testified ambiguously, "You have said it, and in time you will see the Son of Man seated at the right hand of the Almighty, coming on the clouds of Heaven." The high priest condemned Jesus for blasphemy  with a sentence of death .

 Peter, waiting in the courtyard, also denied Jesus three times to bystanders while the interrogations were proceeding just as Jesus had predicted.   

In the morning, the whole assembly brought Jesus to the Roman governor Pontius Pilateunder charges of subverting the nation, opposing taxes to Caesar, and making himself a king . Pilate authorized the Jewish leaders to judge Jesus according to their own law and execute sentencing; however, the Jewish leaders replied that they were not allowed by the Romans to carry out a sentence of death.

Pilate questioned Jesus and told the assembly that there was no basis for sentencing. Upon learning that Jesus was from Galilee, Pilate referred the case to the ruler of Galilee, King Herod, who was in Jerusalem for the Passover Feast. Herod questioned Jesus but received no answer; Herod sent Jesus back to Pilate. Pilate told the assembly that neither he nor Herod found guilt in Jesus; Pilate resolved to have Jesus whipped and released.  Under the guidance of the chief priests, the crowd asked mercy for Barabbas, who had been imprisoned for committing murder during an insurrection. 

Pilate asked what they would have him do with Jesus, and they demanded, "Crucify him".
  
Pilate's wife had seen Jesus in a dream earlier that day, and she forewarned Pilate to "have nothing to do with this righteous man" . Pilate had Jesus flogged and then brought him out to the crowd to release him. The chief priests informed Pilate of a new charge, demanding Jesus be sentenced to death "because he claimed to be God's son." This possibility filled Pilate with fear, and he brought Jesus back inside the palace and demanded to know from where he came.

Coming before the crowd one last time, Pilate declared Jesus innocent and washed his own hands in water to show he has no part in this condemnation. Nevertheless, Pilate handed Jesus over to be crucified in order to forestall a riot  and ultimately to keep his job. 
 
Cheese and crackers, how little human nature has changed.  First, the mob or the crowd of public opinion will always be more exaggerated and more irrational than when an individual is set with the responsibility of making an important decision or acting in a rational manner......  In the Biblical time, saving Barrabas, a very bad man (I mean murder and insurrection is pretty serious stuff) was more palatable to the irrational mob than considering the plight of a Man whose only "crime" could be that he was the son of God.  In addition,  the Roman governor Pontius Pilate, KNEW within his heart that this was an innocent ma, yet in order to assuage his own ambitions and give in to the crowd, he sacrificed a Man much better than himself.  

So how is this much different than today?  As I said, human nature is still the same....... ambition, greed, fear, cowardice and self absorption are all part of the human landscape.  We saw this played out in Ferguson Missouri where the mob influenced a suspension of truth, integrity, and decency.  We witnessed people looting and burning out their own homes, unwilling to tell the truth that their "lying" eyes allowed them to see.  We witnessed this "mob mentality" spread across the nation with lawmakers, sports stars, musicians, adults and children alike flinging their hands in the air and acting on a street thug's fantastical lie.  We witnessed doctors testifying to a scenario regarding the dead teenager that they knew in their hearts was not true.  We saw the mob calling for the head of an innocent man whose life will be forever changed by this miscarriage of justice.

What else do we see today?  Well, just in the same manner that Peter,denied Jesus three times to bystanders while the interrogations were proceeding just as Jesus had predicted, our religious leaders remain silent on any and all matters of Faith in the public arena.  Part of it is fiscal concerns......  many of them have become salaried "churchers".......  meaning that the business of running a church is very expensive and we would not want to lessen the coffers.  The "show" must go on.....  after all, the music, lights and backdrops cost money. Stepping out means the possibility of offending which would bring the show to a grinding halt.  In this case many of them have really outdone Peter..... in the number of denials that is.

And finally, mercy.  We have all fallen short of the glory of God.  Next week the 11 teachers and administrators who were caught cheating will undergo sentencing for racketeering.  Hmmmmmmm don't you think we are going a weeee bit too far with this?  Now hear me out.... it was wrong BUT, we will jail teachers who with some supervision, say for 5 years or so, they could "give back".  The President lessened the sentence for drug dealers...... who will go back to selling dope as soon as they find their "hook up" - it is after all their profession; A bunch of Taliban and Al Queda are running around loose in the Middle East plotting their next caper; Harry Reid lied like a rug in the chamber and then said "so what"; Susan Rice lies every time a camera is pointed in her face; Hillary Clinton is still the front-runner for President of the United States soooooooo.......  Given the fact that the Atlanta 11 at least will impart a level of "value" to society – they are educated teachers who will at least have remorse..... when compared to the latter.......  should we not beg for "mercy"?

Have a really Good Friday.

status_message:
Good Maundy Thursday!

The Shadow of Betrayal

Thursday before Easter. Also referred to as "Holy Thursday" or "Great Thursday" in some Christian denominations,Maundy Thursday Commemorates the Last Supper when Jesus shared the Passover meal with his disciples on the night before he was crucified. In contrast to joyful Easter celebrations when Christians worship their resurrected Savior,Maundy Thursday services are typically more solemn occasions, marked by the shadow of Jesus' betrayal.Wikipedia

The Importance of Money in the Betrayal......

Judas Iscariot questioned whether or not Jesus was indeed the Messiah.   Judas Iscariot was one of the twelve original disciples of Jesus Christ, and son of Simon Iscariot. He is known for the  kiss and betrayal of Jesus to the Sanhedrin for thirty silver coins.  When we get angry and call someone a "Judas"  it is regarding his name –--it often invoked to accuse someone of betrayal. The kiss is the distraction ..... now known as the "kiss of death".

One can, however, look at Judas' betrayal, fast setting in motion the events that led to Jesus' Crucifixion and Resurrection, which, according to traditional Christian theology, brought salvation to humanity.

OK, but back to the "betrayal", which is central to to solemnity of Maundy Thursday.  This week I had a discussion with a friend who belongs to a church denomination that is taking a vote on the "definition of marriage".  One of my favorite lines of Scripture in Proverbs is:

Proverbs 30:18-19 
18 "There are three things that are too amazing for me, four that I do not understand: 19the way of an eagle in the sky, the way of a snake on a rock, the way of a ship on the high seas, and the way of a man with a maiden.

Such beautiful words, evoking in me  a picture of the most natural of all combinations, a man and a woman – the only combination to which natural  procreation is a gift.  In my prayers one of the things that I ask for is the "God Blessed", loving and respectful union of my daughters with a God-fearing, hard working man like their father loves and honors them.
 
Now, here is where it gets tricky, does this mean that we hate the homosexual?  Not at all.  Never hate.  But as we conform ourselves to the ways of the world, unless we re-write the Bible and name it the gospel according to Michael Green or Mary Smith, voting to change and integral of the Word is well convoluted thinking.  The law provides for marriage between a man and a man or a woman and a woman but the Bible does not.  You either have a  Bible based church or a spiritual "based" social group..... not both.  How much more important is the Bible than "Moby Dick", but the "real smart" scholars would step up, balk and speak up if we changed the name of "Moby Dick" to "Moby Charles".  I remember the angst that some people went through over the colorization of some of the classic movies, but changing the Gospel of the origins of man..... nary a hue nor cry. 

Arkansas Gov. Asa Hutchinson says he does not plan to sign the religious freedom bill that sits on his desk right now, instead asking state lawmakers to make changes so the bill mirrors federal law. The first-term Republican governor said he wants his state "to be known as a state that does not discriminate but understands tolerance."
 
Who says that (1) people of Faith naturally want to discriminate and (2) are intolerant by nature?  He also speaks of a generation gap as if all young people think this way also.  

Hutchinson's decision comes in the wake of an uproar in Indiana, where Gov. Mike Pence has faced pressure from businesses, sports associations like the NCAA and popular culture figures to backtrack on a similar religious freedom law he signed last week. In Arkansas, it's been Wal-Mart applying the most pressure. 

So as in the Biblical times, the "betrayal" of the rights of people who feel that their right to religious freedom is being trampled and negated by those who believe that they have the right to call you intolerant or worse if they are not allowed to suppress YOU.  …...... all of this comes back to the betrayal of Jesus to the Sanhedrin for thirty silver coins........ because when these corporations get involved, they are telling you that you won't get your thirty silver coins without the betrayal of your Faith, your Lord  and ultimately your religious freedoms.  Just think, the cheap sneakers, plastic shoes and stretch pants at Wal Mart instead of salvation.......  Your Rights End Where Mine Begin. 

On this solemn day of betrayal, where are the brave clergy boldly speaking up for the flock set asunder under the press of secularism disguised as "political correctness"?  I have watched the "prosperity princes" beg for money from their congregation to buy new planes... all from people, some of which,  who don't have enough to make a proper Sunday meal.  They have television shows, radio broadcasts,  newsletters, websites and the like where they show off their "arm guns" from lifting weights, and preach the coolest sermons about …..... anything safe and  removed and non-disruptive of the flow of the modern thirty silver coins. 

So, in this shadow of betrayal, let us find our voice.   "Render unto Caesar the things that are Caesar's, and unto God the things that are God's"  that is your right under God.  Good Meditation on this day.

status_message:
What do you think?  Perception, Truth and Rights


 I support religious liberty.  I also support anti-discrimination laws.   Religious liberty took a big hit in a 1990 Supreme Court decision that went against American Indians fired after they ingested a hallucinogen in a Native American Church ritual. A law can prohibit any form of worship, Justice Antonin Scalia argued for the majority, as long as it is "neutral (and) generally applicable." 


Outraged over this reasoning, which would have outlawed using wine at the Catholic Mass during Prohibition, Congress responded (nearly unanimously) in 1993 with the Religious Freedom Restoration Act (RFRA). Signed by President Clinton, this act instructed the judiciary to return to its prior approach, in which burdens on individual religious liberty would be unlawful unless the government could show that the burden was necessary to achieve a "compelling government interest" and that the law doing so employed the "least restrictive means." 

http://www.usatoday.com/story/opinion/2015/03/29/indiana-religious-freedom-prothero/70632870/
link_name: Indiana needs to balance gay, religious rights: Column

status_message:
Good Wednesday Evening!

Cheating Yourself.

The phrase man bites dog is a shortened version of an aphorism in journalism which describes how an unusual, infrequent event is more likely to be reported as news than an ordinary, everyday occurrence with similar consequences, such as a dog biting a person ("dog bites man"). 

Often life is like that.....  unusual.  You know "you can't make the stuff up" kind of unusual.  This often occurs when an incentive for "unusual" behavior is present.  For example, when a kid cheats on an exam, when he/she "cuts and pastes" on papers or essays, or various and sundry other childhood short-cuts..... there is no story.  BUT that all changes when you find teachers cheating for students.  Now, that is a story!

Take for example, the Atlanta cheating scandal.    The Atlanta Public Schools cheating scandal refers to the accusation that teachers and principals in the Atlanta Public Schools (APS) district cheated on state-administered standardized tests, and the subsequent fallout. Wikipedia

 Teachers who confessed to cheating blamed "inordinate pressure" to meet targets set by the district and said they faced severe consequences such as a negative evaluation or termination if they didn't. A state report that began in the summer of 2010 found that 44 of 56 Atlanta public schools investigated cheated on the 2009 CRCT, or Criterion-Referenced Competency Tests, a set of tests administered at Georgia public elementary schools to test students in a variety of subjects. The report implicated 38 principals and 140 teachers. 

Apparently, cheating on the 2009 CRCT was originally noticed by the Georgia Office of Student Achievement, when too many incorrect answers were erased and changed to the right answers. Award-winning gains by Atlanta students were based on widespread cheating  .

The investigation tarnishes the 12-year tenure of Superintendent Beverly Hall, who was named US Superintendent of the Year in 2009 largely because of the school system's reported gains – especially in inner-city schools. Beverly Hall recently died due to breast cancer as dozens of educators stood trial for a cheating scandal that happened during her tenure as head of the school district. 

In Atlanta on Wednesday, the city's schoolchildren learned an important lesson by watching what a jury said about some of the school district's former educators.

 Eleven former Atlanta Public Schools educators were convicted of racketeering for their roles in one of the most brazen and pervasive school cheating scandals ever uncovered. They could face years in prison. Another 21 Atlanta educators already had reached plea deals with prosecutors, admitting their roles in the wrongdoing. The defendants, including teachers, a principal and other administrators, were accused of falsifying test results to collect bonuses or keep their jobs in the 50,000-student Atlanta school system. A 12th defendant, a teacher, was acquitted of all charges by the jury.

The racketeering charges carry up to 20 years in prison. Most of the defendants will be sentenced April 8

The only one allowed to remain free on bail was teacher Shani Robinson, because she is expected to give birth soon. 

For many public school teachers, the treatment of teachers in Atlanta is disturbingly familiar : Fear, abuse, threats, retaliation, cover-up, nepotism, misappropriated funds, being asked, "Are you a member of my team?" discovering that your grades were arbitrarily changed, and, in each case, facing the anguishing choice that was really no choice at all: "Should I report it and risk retaliation or go along and keep quiet – while it eats away at me?" 

Shouldn't we want better?

status_message:
Good Monday Evening!

Great Monday.

 "Truly I tell you, if you have faith and do not doubt, not only can you do what was done to the fig tree, but also you can say to this mountain, 'Go, throw yourself into the sea,' and it will be done. If you believe, you will receive whatever you ask for in prayer."

Today is Great Monday of the Holy Week leading up to Easter.  For those not interested in scripture, understand that I am not "preaching" to you.  I am not qualified to do so.  But it is important that you keep an open mind....

Holy Monday, Tuesday, and  Wednesday .........so often the Holy Week is considered one of the beautiful traditions" or "customs", a self evident "part" of our calendar. We take it for granted and enjoy it.   

They were "normal" men who shouted, "Crucify Him!", who spat on Him and nailed Him to the Cross. They hated and killed Him precisely because He was troubling their normal life. It was indeed a perfectly "normal" world which preferred darkness and death to light and life. By the death of Jesus, this "normal" world, this "normal" life was irrevocably condemned, or rather, they revealed their true and abnormal nature ie their inability to receive the - "Now is the judgement of this world." (John 12:31). The Pascha (Passover) of Jesus signified its end to "this world" and it has been at its end since then. This end can last for hundreds of centuries; this does not alter the nature of time in which we live as the "last time." The "fashion of this world passes away..."(1 Corinthians 7:31). 

In the times in which we live, I have heard religion referred to as "fairy dust" and/or a "fairytale"....... This is nothing new as there is truly nothing new under the sun.  Man and woman exist in essentially the same condition they existed in during Biblical times, for those who believe or "ancient" times for those who don't.

Essentially the same 5 fingers on each hand, five toes on each foot;   Same gray matter between the ears and the same reproductive parts that guarantee the next generation will be brought forth from a womb.Our organs work the same as they always did and our mind is still geared towards satisfying the "pleasure principle"  -----   which prefers darkness and "death" to light and life.  What is death/  sometimes it is simply anything that denies your life light......  In the biblical sense it can be;

A proud look (Conceitedness)
A lying tongue (self explanatory)
Hands that shed innocent blood
A heart that devises wicked plots
Feet that are swift to run into mischief
A deceitful witness that uttereth lies
Him that soweth discord among brethren

But think about it.......  all of these things ..... well they are fun!  They are "normal"......  they make us feel REAL good..... at least temporarily. And when you combine them with the right cuss words, drugs and 50 shades of gray......... we might even convince ourselves that they bring us into the "normal light".  

And then what.......?   The other day I found myself watching the quintessential sexy, irreverent "Sex and the City" re-run.....  The main character, Carrie, was obsessing about using "email".  I found myself fascinated that the clothes and hairstyles still looked viable but "e-gads!" ....... who doesn't use "email".  Life is impossible without it!  Technology changes, customs change but the real object of her affection did not - she wanted to get back with her old boyfriend, who she cheated of and would again.  It would not end with them together or even "living happily ever after" ... that was not in their stars but instead of emptiness, they would pretend 'sophisticated angst'.  Unfortunately for those late thirty-somethings and forty-somethings who are now late forty-somethings and fifty-somethings due to the passage of time...... who bought into this "fun" there might be a level of emptiness.......  How long can you sit in cute cafe's talking about every iteration of  sex with people who don't care anything about you before you get bored and irritated?  Not to mention alone and empty.

When my Grandmother was in hospice just 7 short years ago I saw the rooms of women and men essentially in the same condition that she was in.  This facility allowed the residents to have a picture of the patient's "best self".  You would be surprised how beautiful and fit the ladies once were and how handsome and "sexy" some of the men once were. My grandma had her picture up of her sitting on the rocks by the sea.  She looked just like my youngest daughter Austen.  Same fair skin and round face and beautiful hair (nothing like my wiry curly stuff).   I also passed the room of a very sick woman who abused drugs for years and looked much older than 35 as she was suffering from the advanced stages of AIDS and hepatitis.  Drugs were part of her "normal" and i guess at one point it provided a level of what she thought was "happiness and light" needless to say..... she had no picture on her door.

So, you ask, what's the point Angela?

The point is that during this week, regardless of your belief or lack thereof, ask yourself if what you are doing now will provide you with a level of lasting happiness and self gratification.  You began life as a baby and you will end life .... if you live long enough, with just the memories of the best you gave life.  Regardless of the changes in technology which provide you with new cheeks (both on your face and on your back), tighter skin, bigger breasts or other places I heard they are able to enhance...... you will never re-capture the essence or the effervescence of the 18 year old ingenue.  

It is time to build greater "castles" then  you can say to this mountain, 'Go, throw yourself into the sea,' and it will be done. If you believe, you will receive whatever you ask for in prayer."  

Times change but neither human beings nor human nature change.  Give it always your best shot.

status_message:
Good Monday Evening!

Great Monday.

 "Truly I tell you, if you have faith and do not doubt, not only can you do what was done to the fig tree, but also you can say to this mountain, 'Go, throw yourself into the sea,' and it will be done. If you believe, you will receive whatever you ask for in prayer."

Today is Great Monday of the Holy Week leading up to Easter.  For those not interested in scripture, understand that I am not "preaching" to you.  I am not qualified to do so.  But it is important that you keep an open mind....

Holy Monday, Tuesday, and  Wednesday .........so often the Holy Week is considered one of the beautiful traditions" or "customs", a self evident "part" of our calendar. We take it for granted and enjoy it.   

They were "normal" men who shouted, "Crucify Him!", who spat on Him and nailed Him to the Cross. They hated and killed Him precisely because He was troubling their normal life. It was indeed a perfectly "normal" world which preferred darkness and death to light and life. By the death of Jesus, this "normal" world, this "normal" life was irrevocably condemned, or rather, they revealed their true and abnormal nature ie their inability to receive the - "Now is the judgement of this world." (John 12:31). The Pascha (Passover) of Jesus signified its end to "this world" and it has been at its end since then. This end can last for hundreds of centuries; this does not alter the nature of time in which we live as the "last time." The "fashion of this world passes away..."(1 Corinthians 7:31). 

In the times in which we live, I have heard religion referred to as "fairy dust" and/or a "fairytale"....... This is nothing new as there is truly nothing new under the sun.  Man and woman exist in essentially the same condition they existed in during Biblical times, for those who believe or "ancient" times for those who don't.

Essentially the same 5 fingers on each hand, five toes on each foot;   Same gray matter between the ears and the same reproductive parts that guarantee the next generation will be brought forth from a womb.Our organs work the same as they always did and our mind is still geared towards satisfying the "pleasure principle"  -----   which prefers darkness and "death" to light and life.  What is death/  sometimes it is simply anything that denies your life light......  In the biblical sense it can be;

A proud look (Conceitedness)
A lying tongue (self explanatory)
Hands that shed innocent blood
A heart that devises wicked plots
Feet that are swift to run into mischief
A deceitful witness that uttereth lies
Him that soweth discord among brethren

But think about it.......  all of these things ..... well they are fun!  They are "normal"......  they make us feel REAL good..... at least temporarily. And when you combine them with the right cuss words, drugs and 50 shades of gray......... we might even convince ourselves that they bring us into the "normal light".  

And then what.......?   The other day I found myself watching the quintessential sexy, irreverent "Sex and the City" re-run.....  The main character, Carrie, was obsessing about using "email".  I found myself fascinated that the clothes and hairstyles still looked viable but "e-gads!" ....... who doesn't use "email".  Life is impossible without it!  Technology changes, customs change but the real object of her affection did not - she wanted to get back with her old boyfriend, who she cheated of and would again.  It would not end with them together or even "living happily ever after" ... that was not in their stars but instead of emptiness, they would pretend 'sophisticated angst'.  Unfortunately for those late thirty-somethings and forty-somethings who are now late forty-somethings and fifty-somethings due to the passage of time...... who bought into this "fun" there might be a level of emptiness.......  How long can you sit in cute cafe's talking about every iteration of  sex with people who don't care anything about you before you get bored and irritated?  Not to mention alone and empty.

When my Grandmother was in hospice just 7 short years ago I saw the rooms of women and men essentially in the same condition that she was in.  This facility allowed the residents to have a picture of the patient's "best self".  You would be surprised how beautiful and fit the ladies once were and how handsome and "sexy" some of the men once were. My grandma had her picture up of her sitting on the rocks by the sea.  She looked just like my youngest daughter Austen.  Same fair skin and round face and beautiful hair (nothing like my wiry curly stuff).   I also passed the room of a very sick woman who abused drugs for years and looked much older than 35 as she was suffering from the advanced stages of AIDS and hepatitis.  Drugs were part of her "normal" and i guess at one point it provided a level of what she thought was "happiness and light" needless to say..... she had no picture on her door.

So, you ask, what's the point Angela?

The point is that during this week, regardless of your belief or lack thereof, ask yourself if what you are doing now will provide you with a level of lasting happiness and self gratification.  You began life as a baby and you will end life .... if you live long enough, with just the memories of the best you gave life.  Regardless of the changes in technology which provide you with new cheeks (both on your face and on your back), tighter skin, bigger breasts or other places I heard they are able to enhance...... you will never re-capture the essence or the effervescence of the 18 year old ingenue.  

It is time to build greater "castles" then  you can say to this mountain, 'Go, throw yourself into the sea,' and it will be done. If you believe, you will receive whatever you ask for in prayer."  

Times change but neither human beings nor human nature change.  Give it always your best shot.

status_message:
Good Sunday Evening!

The Importance of Carly Fiorina.

She served as chief executive officer of Hewlett-Packard from 1999 to 2005 and previously was an executive at AT&T and its equipment and technology spinoff, Lucent.  

She was the Republican nominee for the United States Senate from California in 2010.   If anyone is at doubt, California is a particularly one party state, with California being a virtual ATM for the President.  In other words, the are great monetary supporters for the president.  

She ran against Barbara Boxer and received 42.2% of the vote.  In addition, Fiorina served as an advisor to Republican John McCain's 2008 presidential campaign.

In 1998, Fortune magazine named her the "most powerful woman in business" in its inaugural listing, and she was included in the Time 100 in 2004 and remained in the Fortune listing throughout her tenure at HP. Fiorina was #10 on the Forbes list of The World's 100 Most Powerful Women for 2004. She became regarded by many as being the first woman to head up a Fortune 20 company, and to have overcome the metaphorical "glass ceiling". http://www.ask.com/wiki/Carly_Fiorina?o=2801&qsrc=999&ad=doubleDown&an=apn&ap=ask.com

Fiorina (then Cara Carleton Sneed) married Todd Bartlem, a Stanford classmate, in June 1977. They divorced in 1984.In 1985, she married AT&T executive Frank Fiorina. It was the second marriage for both. She helped to raise his two daughters Traci and Lori Ann. They attempted to have children together but, as Fiorina puts it: "That wasn't God's plan."

We share a number of things in common, but this one in particular is most key in my mind....:  

On February 20, 2009, Fiorina was diagnosed with breast cancer. She underwent a double mastectomy at Stanford Hospital on March 2, 2009, followed by chemotherapy, which caused her to temporarily lose her hair, and later radiation therapy.(Keep in mind that this was the election cycle)  

 She was given "an excellent prognosis for a full recovery.""Carly Fiorina has surgery for breast cancer". San Francisco Chronicle. Retrieved Mar 20, 2009.

Early in her campaign for the United States Senate seat held by Barbara Boxer, Fiorina told a group of supporters: "I have to say that after chemotherapy, Barbara Boxer just isn't that scary anymore."

This is a fearless woman of accomplishment, a "can do " spirit and the capability of forging her own path.  We should embrace this in the Republican Party.  

Carly Fiorina 2016!!!!

status_message:
Good Saturday Morning!

A Woman's Role.

I frequently change the picture board of this Facebook page in order to commemorate the passage of something significant in history or just to me.  Some of you like the picture, some have questions about it and some outright hate it, however, the main idea is that you simply think about it.  

Todays picture involves the WAAF.  The WAAF - Women's Auxiliary Air Force was formed this month  in 1938, the year before World War Two began. It was originally organised as a support force of women volunteer charged with carrying on the work of the Air Transport Auxiliary which was subsumed as part of the WAAF.

WAAF numbers exceeded 180,000 at its peak in 1943, with over 2,000 women enlisting per week.  Day to day life and prospects were limited for women in that era and many women felt that they wanted to play a part or 'do their bit' for the pre-war effort and quickly joined the WAAF upon its official formation on 28th June 1939, in search of adventure but mainly because they felt the call to be doing something to support their country.

The uniform was a draw for some women, or at least that is what they stated at the time.  They traded in their petticoats and frillies to wear a proper uniform.  They had a chance to do something "less ordinary" and look "less ordinary" as well.

The early publicity for the WAAF advised women that their jobs would fall under three main roles -Driving, Clerical and Administrative Duties and finally.... Cooking.  Joining the WAAF must have seemed like an adventure, however, basically, they would be serving airmen from the various RAF (Royal Air Force) bases in the United Kingdom.

Although their role was primarily listed as support, these women were not "shrinking violets"  for example, during the war 12 WAAF pilots lost their lives, in Reconnaissance Operatives, they analysed  photographs of German targets. and never forget Eileen Younghusband who filtered through to the German's Big Ben message threatening the bombing of London by V2 bombers..... or Noor Inayat Khan, Agent Phono who died at the hands of the Nazis after working covertly as a radio operator in France during the German occupation.

So why this story above others?  Well, a couple of weeks ago I published the picture of Betty Friedan because the Feminine Mystique was published February 19, 1963.  A number of people "disliked" me perhaps because of this but it does not negate the fact that this book was a singularly important body of work .... especially for women.   "The Feminine Mystique begins with an introduction describing what Friedan called "the problem that has no name"—the widespread unhappiness of women in the 1950s and early 1960s. It discusses the lives of several housewives from around the United States who were unhappy despite living in material comfort and being married with children."  

Prior to this time, it was assumed that although it was necessary for men to achieve and explore, women were content in the most basic biological roles.  Those that did not find contentment there were assumed to be "mannish" or lesbians or emotionally disturbed.... not just simply ambitious, curious or intelligent.  The rise of one gender will and should never denigrate the other ... but rather enhance it for both genders... that is.

So, I watch women even today give over their "power" and comfort themselves with being beautiful "playthings" for men.  They do this until it is too late and they realize that as they content themselves with being a "thing", they become replaced by a cuter "thing"........ because "things" have no intrinsic value.

Further, I read the latest sex discrimination case this morning, noting that the woman, Ellen Pao, lost.  The company,Kleiner Perkins Caulfield & Byers, should not be so cocky because in losing, she won and in winning..... they lost.  How so,   In vanquishing their female foe, the venerable venture-capital firm took a PR thumping with countless embarrassing disclosures in court that buttress her argument and painted it in a chauvinistic light.  The locker-room mentality, the lewd and bawdy behavior towards women...... they will lose eventually... they have won the battle not the war.   The reputation of the tech and financial industries' notorious exclusion of women at their highest ranks – a depressing trend underscored by a new study that shows the gender gap in technology is widening as women are being held back by stereotypes and biases.  This continues on.

http://www.usatoday.com/story/tech/columnist/2015/03/27/ellen-pao-sex-discrimination-case-kleiner-perkins-trial/70484588/

So, what does this have to do with politics?  Plenty.  As I drive my many miles to work every morning, the venerable "Ready for Hillary" bumper-stickers stare me in the face at every traffic light.  Precisely what are they ready for?  This is where everything gets tricky.......  most people know how slippery and generally unaccomplished this woman's term in her various office positions has been.  The shrill laugh at inappropriate times, the changing accents --- from high-brow to black slave woman as she declares herself "tard" instead of "tired" when she performs in front of Black audiences. We listen in horror as she states incorrectly that she landed in Iraq under heavy gun-fire and had to run for her life.  One might even imagine the pastel polyester pants suit propelling those legs through the sands of the desert as she runs for cover....... Maybe....

But the real knee-jerk reaction is to "wait for her" because she is a woman.  And we want to see the "underdog" come ahead...  In this case, the "underdog" is a woman.... and she is Hillary.  Right?

Wrong........  Tomorrow I will write a bit about MY "waiting for" moment and the person I would like to speak about is...... Carly Fiorina.for 2016.

status_message:
Invictus: The Unconquerable

Out of the night that covers me,
      Black as the Pit from pole to pole,
I thank whatever gods may be
      For my unconquerable soul.

In the fell clutch of circumstance
      I have not winced nor cried aloud,
Under the bludgeonings of chance
      My head is bloody, but unbowed.

Beyond this place of wrath and tears
      Looms but the horror of the shade,
And yet the menace of the years
      Finds, and shall find me, unafraid.

It matters not how strait the gate,
      How charged with punishments the scroll,
I am the master of my fate:
      I am the captain of my soul.

status_message:
Good Friday Evening!

The Essential and Non-Essential...... in Human Nature,

I love dogs.  I really do.  My dogs, two English Bull Dogs - Winston Churchill and Sir Harry are among the most lovable dogs on the planet.  They play, they stare, the snore......loudly at my bedroom door.  But they play no real purpose --- except for me.  However, I attended a gala tonight to benefit a charity that trains dogs to help the handicapped.  People who either had spinal cord injuries or were born with cerebral palsy would benefit from the training of these smart and "essential" dogs.  These dogs are "essential" for these people to live independent and mobile lives.  These animals are smart, calm and attentive to "their" people who so depend upon them.  The evening was life affirming and essential. 

Another thing that happened to me today was that I received notification from many of you that there is an ugly accusation out on an obscure website regarding an allegation that Allen West sexually harassed two women.  This allegation was quickly promulgated by a local talk person by the name of Joyce Kaufman and she is complicit.  Joyce has a small show that is juxtaposed with Rush Limbaugh so it is imperative that she creates local "buzz" in order to garner an audience. She is approximately 20 years older than my husband and myself (graduating from Roosevelt High-School when we were in pre-school) and a grandmother/great-grandmother (Bubbles?) many, many, many, many times over.

Over the past 6 years my husband, myself and our children have been targeted by this woman for reasons only known to her, but that have primarily centred around a job that she felt she should have gotten as a "chief of staff" in the year 2009.  Not getting the job and the ability to race through the corridors to the Capital and possibly the White House creating mayhem proved to be a "bitter pill" for this perpetually miserable talk show maven.  

As people do, we moved on to different things and different jobs.  Kaufman supposedly jumped out of a moving plane, married again, had a new grandchild on the West Coast, stood in the pouring rain and mud of Port St. Lucie protesting Marco Rubio (we did not know she was out there until the flood watch was announced) and tried to continue burning her torch for a job never had and harassing the West family by utilizing the air waves of WFTL in Fort Lauderdale.The amazing thing is that she has managed to confuse the conservative members of the electorate, promote the destruction of the Republican Party in South Florida and ensure the election of liberals.  All while speaking up for the Tea Party (smile).  All non-essential.  
 
We moved back to Fort Lauderdale, bought a new place in Texas, near to Allen's new position and  forged new careers while taking care of our family, making new friends, doing charity work and making sure that our children get a good start in life.  In addition to our "regular" children, we have managed to support an IDF soldier through college as well as two Chinese exchange students.   We have supported conservative causes and conservative candidates AND helped them get elected..  This is what we do.  We move on, we do better and aim higher.

So, now the question ........Angela....did it happen?  Nope. What did happen was simply this.....  My daughter said that she is  tired of Joyce targeting our family.  Making statements, horning in on our lives.  Both girls have had to endure this human since they were in the 5th and 8th grades.  They are now seniors in college and high school.  We have lived under the spectre of humiliation by this "on air" "personality" that is obsessed with in her words "ruining" and willing to use the air waves of a radio station to do so. 

Bottom line, putting up with the bitter bile of this person  is intolerable to my husband, my children and me ... we are one.  The last line of insult that any person of color will ever have to deal with is sexual allegations.  You see this is what people who want to ruin Black people do...... they make a sexual allegation....  Herman Cain and Jennifer Carroll are the latest targets in recent years.  This will not stand.....  

I am unafraid and a difficult person when necessary.

Isaiah 54:17

  "no weapon forged against me will prevail, and I will refute every tongue that accuses me."  

Back to the news tomorrow!

status_message:
Good Wednesday Morning!!!!!

Where in the World is Bowe Bergdahl?

In June 2009, Bergdahl left his base in eastern Afghanistan. Deserted.  It's been nearly a year since Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl returned to the United States as part of a prisoner exchange and since the Army began a formal investigation into his disappearance from his unit. 

The Army still hasn't made public its findings. In January the Army stated that a decision on whether to charge Bergdahl -- and what those charges would be -- could come "very soon, imminently." But no decision has been announced.Gen. Mark Milley, head of U.S. Army Forces Command, who will decide what to do.... next.

So...... what's taking soooooo long?

National Security Adviser Susan Rice said last June that Bergdahl "served the United States with honor and distinction."  Her perspective on MANY things --- NIgeria and Benghazi... to name just two, are very "other-worldly/unique"  so I would not put too much credence to that statement. 

Bergdahl, who's now 28, was taken by the Haqqani terrorist network. But the circumstances of Bergdahl's departure from his base and how willingly he left have not been clear.Some members of Bergdahl's platoon have criticized him, labeling Bergdahl a deserter.

"I was pissed off then, and I am even more so now with everything going on," former Sgt. Matt Vierkant, a member of Bergdahl's platoon when he went missing on June 30, 2009, told CNN last year. "Bowe Bergdahl deserted during a time of war, and his fellow Americans lost their lives searching for him."

Bergdahl was freed in May when President Barack Obama agreed to swap five Taliban prisoners who had been detained in Guantanamo Bay to secure Bergdahl's freedom, sending those detainees to Qatar.  And he was promoted..... and awarded back pay..... and his parents sashayed into the White House --- Mom wore a cute dress and Dad, a Taliban beard.  Quite a "hero's welcome" in the White House Rose Garden.

His hometown of Hailey, Idaho, had planned a parade to celebrate Bergdahl's homecoming but later canceled that celebration.  A couple of the released contacted their old Taliban crew....... but Bob and Jani Bergdahl had a wonderful time with the President.

Bergdahl has remained on active duty at an administrative job at Fort Sam Houston in San Antonio, Texas. There, the Army assigned Bergdahl a "sponsor" to help him adjust to life in his new post.   He has been spotted enjoying a bite to eat and shopping.  

Seems a bit unfair...... doesn't it?

 The families of other U.S. hostages taken by terror groups have complained that the Bergdahl swap also suggested there's a price American leaders are willing to pay in exchange for the safe return of U.S. citizen.  

Remember those terrorists we sent back to Yemen for their safekeeping and tracking?

What will happen to them now that Yemen may have bigger "fish to fry" in the way of its very own civil war brewing up?   No one really knows where these five are. 

Remember, they made it clear that the 5 blokes would not return to Al Qaeda.......  Why would they?  The 5 guys have ties to the Taliban NOT Al Qaeda........ a little detail that was left out.... Just a little one.

If we think about it, however, we might deduce that the five guys are not in the burger business nor have they taken up milk and honey farming.......

So..... back to the original question..... Where in the World is Bowe Bergdahl?

status_message:
Good Monday Afternoon!

May I Just Have a Latte, Burrito and Drop my Kid off at Day Care?

Can we just stop being hassled?  Starbuck's Coffee stores  had begun writing "Race Together" on customers' cups, as a means of starting a racial conversation with customers, one week later…… the practice ended.  Why?  "The campaign has been criticized as opportunistic and inappropriate, coming in the wake of racially charged events such as national protests over police killings of black males." http://www.foxnews.com/leisure/2015/03/23/starbucks-baristas-stop-writing-race-together-on-cups/

Starbucks holds around 33 percent of the market share for coffee in the U.S. It sells almost as much coffee as do fast food and convenience stores combined, even though it the bulk of its consumers are in cities or upscale suburban areas. Starbucks' primary target market is men and women aged 25 to 40. They account for almost half (49 percent) of its total business.  Young adults, aged 18 to 24, total 40 percent of Starbucks' sales. Starbucks positions itself as a place college students can hang out, study, write term papers and meet people.  So the chain is fairly upscale, very hip and not inexpensive.

The average worker at a Starbuck's Coffee outlet is a part-timer.  At Starbucks, "baristas" make $8.80 an hour, on average.  Less per hour on average than WalMart……  Most of the workers at the store in my neighborhood and in some of the cities that I have visited are teens to early 20's.  So…… I ask you, on your busy morning rushing to get your favorite coffee brew, do you have as your mission, the desire to carry on a racial discussion with a local teen?

According to Chipotle, their  "Cultivating Thought" program "invites all of us to stop for one minute of our busy lives and read something special. As a writer, I think we all should find our daily spot to stop and meet our thoughts."

Quotes such as "I love the idea of unexpected stories in unexpected places."; "I thought it might be a good thing to open other eyes."; "Have you ever run into someone with no teeth and asked, 'What happened?'"; "'I miss them, Mami.' All those words I had to leave behind. Also, words that in English didn't carry the same feeling."……. are supposed to make you feel …. something ….. while eating your burrito or other concoction ….  Or maybe  words written by authors like authors like Toni Morrison, Malcolm Gladwell and George Saunders will lessen the pain of eating calorie bomb quasi Mexican delights.   

One quote that I find very curious…….  "Hope that, in future, all is well, everyone eats free, no one must work, all just sit around feeling love for one another," is one such insightful snippet you can expect to see on the broad side of your paper bag.
Wouldn't that defeat the purpose of their business continuity plan?  If everyone ate free and did not work…. Where would that leave Chipotles?

And finally, Bureaucrats from the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) will weigh and measure children in daycare as part of a study mandated by First Lady Michelle Obama's Healthy Hunger-Free Kids Act.

 The agency published a notice in the Federal Register on Friday proposing data collection on what meals are served in professional and home daycare facilities and how much physical activity children perform.  Aside from assessing how healthy the food in daycare is, the USDA will also check the weight and height of roughly 3,000 children.

"Children will be asked to cooperate with study staff who will weigh and measure them for the Standing Height and Weight Form," the notice said.

The study is required by section 223 of Healthy Hunger-Free Kids Act, which was championed by Mrs. Obama and passed in 2010. The main aspect of the law implemented new standards for school lunches.http://weaselzippers.us/217911-michelle-obama-mandate-to-force-daycare-providers-to-weigh-measure-children-and-report-data-to-federal-government/

So I ask again…….  May I Just Have a Latte, Burrito and Drop my Kid off at Day Care?

status_message:
Significant in History:  In 1963, "The Feminine Mystique" by Betty Friedan was first published by W.W. Norton & Co

In 1957, Friedan was asked to conduct a survey of her former Smith College classmates for their 15th anniversary reunion; the results, in which she found that many of them were unhappy with their lives as housewives, prompted her to begin research for The Feminine Mystique, conducting interviews with other suburban housewives, as well as researching psychology, media, and advertising. She originally intended to publish an article on the topic, not a book, but no magazine would publish her article.

The Feminine Mystique begins with an introduction describing what Friedan called "the problem that has no name"—the widespread unhappiness of women in the 1950s and early 1960s. It discusses the lives of several housewives from around the United States who were unhappy despite living in material comfort and being married with children.[5]
 
Chapter 1: Friedan points out that the average age of marriage was dropping and the birthrate was increasing for women throughout the 1950s, yet the widespread trend of unhappy women persisted, although American culture insisted that fulfillment for women could be found in marriage and housewifery; this chapter concludes by declaring "We can no longer ignore that voice within women that says: 'I want something more than my husband and my children and my home.'"[6]
 
Chapter 2: Friedan shows that the editorial decisions concerning women's magazines were being made mostly by men, who insisted on stories and articles that showed women as either happy housewives or unhappy careerists, thus creating the "feminine mystique"—the idea that women were naturally fulfilled by devoting their lives to being housewives and mothers. Friedan notes that this is in contrast to the 1930s, at which time women's magazines often featured confident and independent heroines, many of whom were involved in careers.[7]
 
Chapter 3: Friedan recalls her own decision to conform to society's expectations by giving up her promising career in psychology to raise children, and shows that other young women still struggled with the same kind of decision. Many women dropped out of school early to marry, afraid that if they waited too long or became too educated, they would not be able to attract a husband. Friedan argues at the end of the chapter that although theorists discuss how men need to find their identity, women are expected to be autonomous. She states, "Anatomy is woman's destiny, say the theorists of femininity; the identity of woman is determined by her biology."[8] Friedan goes onto argue that the problem is women needing to mature and find their human identity. She argues, "In a sense that goes beyond any woman's life, I think this is a crisis of women growing up— a turning point from an immaturity that has been called femininity to full human identity."[8]
 
Chapter 4: Friedan discusses early American feminists and how they fought against the assumption that the proper role of a woman was to be solely a wife and mother. She notes that they secured important rights for women, including education, the right to pursue a career, and the right to vote.[9]
 
Chapter 5: Friedan, who had a degree in psychology, criticizes Sigmund Freud (whose ideas were very influential in America at the time of her book's publication). She notes that Freud saw women as childlike and as destined to be housewives, once pointing out that Freud wrote, "I believe that all reforming action in law and education would break down in front of the fact that, long before the age at which a man can earn a position in society, Nature has determined woman's destiny through beauty, charm, and sweetness. Law and custom have much to give women that has been withheld from them, but the position of women will surely be what it is: in youth an adored darling and in mature years a loved wife." Friedan also points out that Freud's unproven concept of "penis envy" had been used to label women who wanted careers as neurotic, and that the popularity of Freud's work and ideas elevated the "feminine mystique" of female fulfillment in housewifery into a "scientific religion" that most women were not educated enough to criticize.[10]
 
Chapter 6: Friedan criticizes functionalism, which attempted to make the social sciences more credible by studying the institutions of society as if they were parts of a social body, as in biology. Institutions were studied in terms of their function in society, and women were confined to their sexual biological roles as housewives and mothers as well as being told that doing otherwise would upset the social balance. Friedan points out that this is unproven and that Margaret Mead, a prominent functionalist, had a flourishing career as an anthropologist.[9]
 
Chapter 7: Friedan discusses the change in women's education from the 1940s to the early 1960s, in which many women's schools concentrated on non-challenging classes that focused mostly on marriage, family, and other subjects deemed suitable for women, as educators influenced by functionalism felt that too much education would spoil women's femininity and capacity for sexual fulfillment. Friedan says that this change in education arrested girls in their emotional development at a young age, because they never had to face the painful identity crisis and subsequent maturation that comes from dealing with many adult challenges.[9]
 
Chapter 8: Friedan notes that the uncertainties and fears during World War II and the Cold War made Americans long for the comfort of home, so they tried to create an idealized home life with father as the breadwinner and mother as the housewife.[11] Friedan notes that this was helped along by the fact that many of the women who worked during the war filling jobs previously filled by men faced dismissal, discrimination, or hostility when the men returned, and that educators blamed over-educated, career-focused mothers for the maladjustment of soldiers in World War II. Yet as Friedan shows, later studies found that overbearing mothers, not careerists, were the ones who raised maladjusted children.[9]
 
Chapter 9: Friedan shows that advertisers tried to encourage housewives to think of themselves as professionals who needed many specialized products in order to do their jobs, while discouraging housewives from having actual careers, since that would mean they would not spend as much time and effort on housework and therefore would not buy as many household products, cutting into advertisers' profits.[9]
 
Chapter 10: Friedan interviews several full-time housewives, finding that although they are not fulfilled by their housework, they are all extremely busy with it. She postulates that these women unconsciously stretch their home duties to fill the time available, because the feminine mystique has taught women that this is their role, and if they ever complete their tasks they will become unneeded.[9]
 
Chapter 11: Friedan notes that many housewives have sought fulfillment in sex, unable to find it in housework and children; Friedan notes that sex cannot fulfill all of a person's needs, and that attempts to make it do so often drive married women to have affairs or drive their husbands away as they become obsessed with sex.[9]
 
Chapter 12: Friedan discusses the fact that many children have lost interest in life or emotional growth, attributing the change to the mother's own lack of fulfillment, a side effect of the feminine mystique. When the mother lacks a self, Friedan notes, she often tries to live through her children, causing the children to lose their own sense of themselves as separate human beings with their own lives.[9]
 
Chapter 13: Friedan discusses Abraham Maslow's hierarchy of needs and notes that women have been trapped at the basic, physiological level, expected to find their identity through their sexual role alone. Friedan says that women need meaningful work just as men do to achieve self-actualization, the highest level on the hierarchy of needs.[9]
 
Chapter 14: In the final chapter of The Feminine Mystique, Friedan discusses several case studies of women who have begun to go against the feminine mystique. She also advocates a new life plan for her women readers, including not viewing housework as a career, not trying to find total fulfillment through marriage and motherhood alone, and finding meaningful work that uses their full mental capacity. She discusses the conflicts that some women may face in this journey to self-actualization, including their own fears and resistance from others. For each conflict, Friedan offers examples of women who have overcome it. Friedan ends her book by promoting education and meaningful work as the ultimate method by which American women can avoid becoming trapped in the feminine mystique, calling for a drastic rethinking of what it means to be feminine, and offering several educational and occupational suggestions
